1749: tādī́tnā, adv. then. [perhaps instr. (1112d) of *tādītna, and this fr. *tadi-tna, ‘of that time,’ and this fr. *tadi (1245e), correl. of yadi.]
1750: tādṛ́ś, a. such. [see 518: for declension, see dṛ́ś.]
1753: tāmasa, a. dark; pertaining to darkness or the guṇa called tamas. [támas.]
1755: tārā, f. star. [form of transition to the a-declension (399) from tṛ́, see under stṛ́.]
1756: tāvac-chata, f. -ī, a. having or embracing so many hundreds. [tāvant (1249a) + śata.]
1758: tā́vant [457], 	—1. adj. so great; so much; so many, 1054; extending so far, 1019; lasting so long, 589; correl. w. yāvant, 1019, 1054; 	—2. tāvat, as adv. so much; so far; to such an extent, 9514; so long; for a while, 191; yāvat…tāvat: as long as…so long, 156, 323, 4018; when…then, 4415; just as…then, 227; tāvat…yāvat, so long…as, 192, 423; 	—3. at once; now, 2420, 346, 5317; 	—3a. w. 1st pers. pres. ind., first, before doing any thing else, at once, 2018, 238, 3811; 	—3b. w. imperative: at once, 2423; tāvat…tatas or paścāt, first …then or afterwards, 2718, 384; 	—4. concessively, iha samaye, tāvat, in this case, one must admit, 4110; 	—5. emphasizing, like eva, what precedes, 304, 257. [pron. root ta, 517.]
1760: √tij (tejáyati; tejayā́m āsa; tejitá). be sharp. [orig. *stig: cf. στίζω, ‘prick,’ στίγ-μα, ‘prick’; Lat. in-stīgāre, ‘prick on’; Eng. stick, ‘to pierce.’]
1761: títhi, m. f. a lunar day (of which there are 15 in a half-lunation).
1762: tirás, 	—1. prep. through; across; 	—2. as adv. crossways, sideways; aside; w. kṛ [1713, 10784], put aside, treat disrespectfully,  scold. [√tṛ, ‘cross’: cf. Lat. trans, ‘across.’]
1764: tiryaktva, n. condition of a beast. [tiryak, middle stem of tiryañc, 1249a: 1239.]
1765: tiryáñc [409d], 	—1. a. directed across; horizontal; 	—2. as subst. m. n. beast (going horizontally, as opposed to man, who walks upright--ūrdhva); 	—3. acc. s. n. tiryak, as adv. across. [tiras or tir, w. añc, 409d: tir, like tiras, is akin w. √tṛ.]
1766: tilá, m. 	—1. the sesame plant, Sesamum indicum; 	—2. its seed, which is eaten, and furnishes good oil.
1768: tīra, n. shore or bank. [prop. ‘place of crossing or going into the water,’ √tṛ.]
1769: √tu (távīti [633]; tūtā́va [7864]). have power; be strong. [orig. ‘swell, grow’: cf. τύ-λη, ‘swelling, lump,’ Corcyraean τῦ-μο-ς, ‘mound’; AS. ϸūma, ‘the big (finger),’ Eng. thumb; further, túm-ra, ‘fat, strong’; Lat. tum-ulus, ‘mound,’ tum-or, ‘swelling.’]
1770: tú, pcl. never at beg. of sentence. 	—1. w. imperative, pray; 	—2. in sooth, 7810; 	—3. but, 812, 2613, 3410, etc.; on the other hand, 204; tu…tu, on the one hand…on the other, 216, 17; so…, …tu, …tu, 603; na tv eva tu, but by no means, 6310, 643; kāmaṃ tu…na tu, see kāmam; kiṃ tu, nevertheless, 395; 	—4. used loosely: as equiv. to ca, 581; often as a mere expletive [1122a4], e. g. 49, 6413b.
1771: tu, pron. root of 2nd pers, see tvad.
1773: √tud (tudáti; tutóda; tunná). strike; push. [cf. Τῡδεύς, ‘The Hammer, Martel’; Lat. tundo, tu-tud-i, ‘strike, struck’; Goth. stautan, Ger. stossen, ‘strike.’] + ā, strike at, pick at.
1774: √tur (turáti, -te). press onward swiftly [subsidiary form of √tṛ (242) and allied w. √tvar.]
1775: 1turá, a. 	—1. swift, esp. of horses; -am, as adv. swiftly, in turaṃga; --2. quick, ready, willing, 7817. [√tur.]
1777: turaṃga, m. horse. [‘swiftly going,’ turam + ga, see 1tura: for mg, cf. khaga.]
1779: √tul (toláyati; tolayā́m āsa; tolayiṣyáti; tolitá; -tólya). --1. raise up; 	—2. esp. raise up a thing so as to find its weight; weigh; 	—3. counterpoise; 	—4. equal. [orig. mg, ‘bear, i. e. hold up’: in the cognates,  the mg ‘bear, i. e. endure’ appears: cf. Lat. tul-i, ‘endured’; Goth. ϸul-an, Eng. thole, ‘endure’; Ger. Ge-dul-d, ‘endurance’;  also ἔ-τλη-ν, ‘bore,’ πολύ-τλᾱ-ς, ‘much enduring’; Lat. lātus, *tlā-tus, ‘borne.’]
1780: tulā́, f. balance; weight; equality. [√tul: cf. Anglo-Indian tola, about 180 grains troy: cf. τάλαντον, ‘balance, weight.’]
1781: tulya, a. keeping the balance with; equal to; like. [tulā, 1212d 4 end.]
1782: tulyākṛti, a. having like appearance; alike. [ākṛti.]
1783: tuví, a. in cpds. mighty; much; many. [√tu, 1155.]
1784: tuvi-bādhá, a. distressing many (enemies) or besetting (them) sore.
1787: √tuṣ (túṣyati, -te; tutóṣa; tuṣṭá; tóṣṭum; -túṣya; toṣáyati). become quiet; be satisfied or pleased; caus. satisfy; gratify. + sam, caus. satisfy.
1789: tūṣṇī́m, adv. silently, in silence. [prob. fr. an obsolete *tūṣṇa, ‘silent,’ √tuṣ, 1111d.]
1790: √tṛ (tárati, -te; tiráti, -te; tatā́ra, terús [794e]; átārīt; tariṣyáti, -te; tīrṇá; tártum; tīrtvā́; -tī́rya; tāráyati). 	—1. cross over (a water, the sky); 	—2. get across or to the end; get through, escape; survive. [cf. τέρμων, Lat. terminus, ‘boundary’: see √trā and tiras: for treatment of root-vowel,  see 242.] + ava, descend, esp. from heaven to earth; come down, esp. of divine beings who become incarnate as men; alight; betake one's self to; caus. take down or off. + ud, come up out of the water. + abhy-ud, come out of the water unto, cross the water unto, 894. + pra, take to the water; start on. + vi, cross through; traverse.
1792: tṛcá, m. n. strophe of three stanzas. [tri + ṛc, 243, 1315c.]
1793: tṛ́ṇa, n. grass. [cf. (θρόνα=) τρόνα, ‘flowers, herbs’; Eng. thorn; Ger. Dorn, ‘thorn.’]
1794: tṛtī́ya, a. third. [fr. tri, through trita, 243, 4874: cf. τρί-τος, Lat. ter-tius, Eng. thir-d, Ger. dri-tte, ‘third.’]
1795: √tṛd (tṛṇátti, tṛntté; tatárda, tatṛdé; tṛṇṇá; -tṛ́dya). split; bore; open. + anu, bore after (waters), release, make flow.
1796: √1tṛp (tṛ́pyati, -te [761a]; tatárpa; átṛpat; trapsyáti; tṛptá; -tṛ́pya; tarpáyati). be satisfied; become content; --caus. satisfy,  please; nourish. [cf. τέρπω, ‘satisfy, please,’ τρέφω, ‘nourish.’] + ā, become content or glad.
1797: √2tṛp, steal, not actually occurring in vbl forms, but rendered probable by the deriv. tṛpu, ‘thief,’ the cpds asu- and paśu-tṛp, and by the Avestan √tṛf, ‘steal.’
1798: √tṛṣ (tṛ́ṣyati; tatárṣa; átṛṣat; tṛṣitá; tarṣáyati). be thirsty. [cf. τέρσ-ομαι, ‘become dry’; Lat. torret, *tors-et, ‘grows dry, scorches’; Eng. noun thirs-t; Ger. dorr-et, ‘grows dry’; also Lat. terra, *ters-a, ‘the dry (land).’]
1801: téjas, n. 	—1. sharpness, edge; 	—2. tip of flame or ray; gleaming splendor, 16; fire; 	—3. (splendor, i. e.) beauty of person, 810ff.; 	—4. (like Eng. fire, i. e.) energy, vigor, power; 	—5. moral or magic power, 1123; influence, dignity, 958; majesty, 16, 24. [√tij: observe that ἀκμή has mgs 1 and 4.]
1802: téna, adv. in that way, 4717; so; therefore, 187, etc.; yatas or yad or yena…tena, for the reason that…, therefore, 308, 576, 649. [pron. root ta, 1112a: of like derivation and mg is τῷ.]
1804: toká, n. creation, progeny. [cf. √takṣ and √tvakṣ, and túc.]
1805: toraṇa, n. arched portal; arch. [‘passage,’ √tur, subsidiary form of √tṛ, ‘cross, pass.’]
1806: tyá [499a], pron. that; that well-known (like Lat. ille).
1807: tyakta-jīvita, a. having life set aside, risking one's life, brave.
1809: √tyaj (tyájati, -te; tatyā́ja, tatyajé; átyākṣīt; tyakṣyáti, -te; tyaktá; tyáktum; tyaktvā́; -tyájya; tyajyáte; tyājáyati). --1. withdraw from; leave in the lurch; abandon (dove, goat, tree); 	—2. renounce (passions, use of a language); relinquish (exertion); lay aside (a certain form, an earthly body); set aside, i. e. risk (life). [cf. σέβομαι, ‘shrink back from in awe, revere.’] + pari, leave to one's fate (a jackal); abandon; leave (one's party); relinquish or give up (play, food, affairs); parityakta, (abandoned by, i. e.) separated from, 663.
1812: trayá, a. triple, threefold, 5713; as n. triad, triplet, τριάς. [tri, 4894.]
1813: √tras (trásati; tatrā́sa, tatrasús, treṣús [794e2]; átrāsīt; trasiṣyáti; trastá). tremble; fear. [cf. τρέω, τρέσ-σε, ‘tremble, trembled’; Lat. terreo, ‘affright’; a-trastas and ἄ-τρεστος, ‘unterrified.’]
1814: trasádasyu, m. Trasadasyu, a generous prince, the favorite of the gods, and descended from Purukutsa. [Perhaps for trasád-dasyu, ‘affrighting the evil beings,’ see 13094. √tras.]
1815: √trā (trā́ti, trā́te [628]; trā́yate [761c]; tatré; átrāsta; trāsyáte; trātá; trā́tum; trātvā́). protect; rescue; rescue from, w. abl. [collateral form of √tṛ (‘get through or across’), w. a caus. mg, ‘bring through or across (trouble).’]
1819: trí [482c], num. three. [cf. τρεῖς, τρία, Lat. trēs, tria, Eng. three, Ger. drei, ‘three.’]
1821: tríkadruka, m. pl. perhaps designation of certain Soma-vessels, three in number. [cf. trí and kadrū́.]
1822: tri-kāla, n. the three times, present, past, and future. [kāla, masc.: 1312.]
1823: trikāla-jña, a. knowing present, past, and future; omniscient.
1824: tri-daśá [declined like kāma, 330], m. pl. the three times ten, the thirty, a name in round numbers for the 33 deities (12 Adityas,  8 Vasus, 11 Rudras, 2 Aśvins), i. e. the gods. [tri + daśa, 477c: cf. triṃśat.]
1825: tridaśeśvara, m. pl. lords of the gods, i. e. the four chief gods, Indra, Agni, Varuna,  and Yama. [īśvara.]
1826: tri-divá, n. the triple or third i. e. highest heaven. [dív, 1315c: 13123.]
1827: tri-dhā́tu, a. having three parts, tri-partite,  threefold. [acct, 1300c.]
1828: tri-pada, f. -ī, a. having (taken) three steps.
1829: tri-rātrá, n. space of three nights, trinoctium.  [rā́tri, 1315b, 13123, 4: cf. the Eng. usage in sen-night, fort-night.]
1830: tri-vidyā, f. the three sciences, i. e. Vedas. [13123.]
1831: trí-vidha, a. of three sorts, threefold. [vidhā, 1302c 5: acct, 1300c.]
1832: tri-vṛ́t, a. threefold, tri-partite. [‘turning thrice, with three turns.’]
1833: tri-veda, in cpds and derivs. the three Vedas. [13123.]
1834: tri-ṣavaṇa, a. pertaining to the three Soma-pressings; -am, adv. at morning, noon, and evening. [savana.]
1835: trís, adv. thrice. [see tri: cf. τρίς, Lat. ter, *ters, ‘thrice’: Eng. thrice is a gen. form, cognate in root only.]
1836: traividya, n. study of the three Vedas. [trividyā.]
1837: traivedika, a. relating to the three Vedas. [triveda, 1222c 2.]
1839: tvá, pron. stem of 2d pers., see tvad.
1840: √tvakṣ, work, principally in derivs., and ident. w. takṣ.
1843: tvát, abl. of tva, and used in place of tva in cpds: by Hindus written tvad, q. v. [494.]
1844: tvat-kṛte, for the sake of thee. [1314f, 1130: tvat represents the stem tva, and in gen. relation.]
1845: tvad [491], so-called stem [494] of 2d pers. pron. thou; see tvat. [w. the real root tu, cf. Doric τύ, Lat. tū, AS. ðū, Eng. thou, Ger. du, ‘thou.’]
1846: √tvar (tvárate; tatvaré; tūrṇá [cf. 957b], tvaritá; tvaráyati). hasten; tvarita, having hastened, in haste. [see √√tur, tṛ.]
1848: tváṣṭṛ, m. 	—1. wright, workman, 756; 	—2. Twashtar, the artificer of the gods (703), former of fruit of the womb, giver of growth and long life (8615), father of Saranyū (8512). [√tvakṣ, 221.]
1852: √daṃś or daś (dáśati [746]; dadáṃśa; daśiṣyáti; daṣṭá; daṃṣṭvā́; -dáśya). bite. [cf. δάκνω, ‘bite’; Goth. tahjan, ‘rend, tear.’]
1854: dáṃṣṭra, m. large tooth; tusk; fang. [√daṃś, 1185b.]
1855: daṃṣṭrin, a. having tusks or large teeth. [daṃṣṭra.]
1856: √dakṣ (dákṣati, -te; dadakṣé; dakṣiṣyáte ). act. suit; mid. be able or dexterous or strong. [cf. dakṣa and dakṣiṇa.]
1857: dákṣa, a. able, dexterous, strong; as m. ability, faculty, strength, power; esp. spiritual power, will; dakṣa and kratu, will and understanding (as faculties of the manas, ‘soul’). [√dakṣ: cf. δεξιός, ‘clever, right,’ and dakṣiṇa.]
1858: dákṣiṇa, a. 	—1. clever, able; and so 	—2. (as opp. to awkward, gauche), right, of the hand, hasta, e. g. 10211; so pāṇi, 605; foot, pāda, 605; side, pārśva, 10212; 	—3. southern (because in prayer the face is turned eastward: cf. uttara 3), 1058; sc. agni, southern fire, 1023N.; 	—4. as f., dakṣiṇā, sc. go, the able, i. e. fruitful cow, milch cow; milch cow as the customary reward for conducting a sacrifice; then, 	—5. in general, any reward or present for the sacrificing priest, see 1065; so 952, 3; --see also adv. dakṣiṇā. [√dakṣ: cf. δεξιός, Lat. dexter, ‘clever, right’; Goth. taihsva, ‘right hand’: from dakṣiṇa in mg 3, comes Deccan, name of the country south of Hindustan, lit. ‘the South.’]
1861: dakṣiṇā́, adv. southerly; toward the south. [dákṣiṇa: acct, 1112e.]
1862: dakṣiṇāgní, m. the southern fire, 1032, cf. 1022N.
1864: dakṣiṇā́-pravaṇa, a. sloping to the south. [dakṣiṇā, adv.]
1866: dakṣiṇāyana, n. south-course (of the sun), or the half-year from the summer to the winter solstice. [dakṣiṇa + ayana.]
1867: dakṣiṇāraṇya, n. the southern forest (a forest in the Deecan). [dakṣiṇa + araṇya.]
1868: dákṣiṇāvant, a. abounding in gifts to the priests, i. e. (from the point of view of the priests) pious. [dákṣiṇā: see dakṣiṇa 5.]
1869: dagdhá, a. 	—1. burned; 	—2. pained, tortured; 	—3. wretched, good-for-nothing, cursed, damned. [ppl. of √dah: for mg 2, cf. √śuc.]
1870: dagdhodara, n. one's cursed belly. [dagdha + udara.]
1871: daṇḍá, m. stick; staff (of Brahman), 5923; mace, 978; rod as symbol of dominion and punishment. [cf. δένδρον, ‘tree.’]
1872: daṇḍa-bhaya, m. fear of the rod.
1873: daṇḍín, a. bearing a staff; as m. warder. [daṇḍa.]
1874: dattá, a. given; as m. (a son) given (by his parents to others for adoption); common at end of proper names, esp. of Vaiśyas. [ppl. of √1dā, 955c.]
1875: dadṛh, a. firm; dadhṛ́k, acc. s. n., as adv. firmly. [√dṛh.]
1876: dadhán [431], n. sour milk; curds. [orig., perhaps, ‘milk,’ fr. √2dhā.]
1878: dadhi-karṇa, m. Curd-ear, name of a cat. [‘having curd-ears, i. e. ears as white as curds.’]
1880: dánt [396], m. tooth. [cf. ὀδόντα, Lat. dentem, Goth. tunϸus, AS. tōð, Eng. tooth, Old High Ger. zand, Ger. Zahn, ‘tooth.’]
1882: √dabh or dambh (dábhati; dadā́bha, dadámbha, debhús; ádabhat; dabdhá; dábdhum). harm with guile; hurt; deceive.
1884: √dam (dā́myati [763]; dāntá [955a]; damitvā́; -dámya; damáyati). 	—1. he tame; 	—2. tame; conquer; become master;  control. [cf. δαμάω, Lat. domāre, ‘tame’; Eng. tame, Ger. zahm, ‘tame.’]
1885: dám, n. house. [cf. δῶ, ‘house’: see under dáma.]
1886: dáma, m. n. house, home. [cf. δόμος, Lat. domus, ‘house, home’: it is not certain whether dáma comes from √dam and so means lit. ‘the place where one is master,  one's Gebiet,’ or whether it is to be connected w. δέμω, ‘build’: in the latter case, it would mean lit., like Ger. Bau, ‘a building,’ and should be connected w. AS. timber, *tem-ra, ‘building-material, a building, ’ Eng. timber, ‘building-material,’ Ger. Zimmer, ‘building-material, a building, a room.’]
1887: damá, 	—1. a. conquering, at end of cpds; as m. 	—2. Dama, i. e. Victor, name of a son of Bhīma; 	—3. self-control. [√dam: cf. Ἱππό-δαμος, ‘Horse-tamer,’ etc.]
1888: damana, 	—1. a. conquering, at end of cpds; 	—2. as m. Damana, i. e. Vincent, name of a priestly sage, and of a son of Bhīma. [√dam: cf. Lat. dominus, ‘master.’]
1889: damayantī, f. Damayantī, i. e. Victoria, name of Bhīma's daughter. [‘conquering (men),’ fr. √dam, 1043. 5.]
1890: dám-pati, m. master of the house; as dual, master and mistress, man and wife; pair. [acct, 1267a.]
1892: √day (dáyate; dayā́m āsa; dayitá). 	—1. part; allot; 	—2. take part in; sympathize with; have tender feeling for; love; --dayita, loved, dear; as f., -tā, wife. [for 1, cf. κρέα δαίετο,, ‘parted, carved the meat’; for 2, cf. δαίεται ἦτορ, ‘heart is divided or takes part in (?), i. e. sympathizes.’]
1898: daridra, a. wandering about; mendicant; poor; as m. poor man. [fr. intens. of √1drā, ‘run about,’ 1147b2: for mg, cf. Eng. tramp, in its American sense of ‘vagrant beggar.’]
1899: darpa, m. wildness; wantonness; impudence;  pride. [√dṛp.]
1900: darbhá, m. grass-tuft; grass used at sacrificial ceremonies, esp. Kuśa-grass, Poa cynosuroides. [√dṛbh.]
1901: darśa, m. sight; the moon when just becoming visible; the new moon; the day or festival of new moon. [√dṛś.]
1902: darśaka, a. 	—1. seeing; 	—2. (fr. caus.) showing, making clear. [dṛś.]
1903: darśatá, a. to be seen; visible. [√dṛś, 1176c.]
1904: dárśana, a. seeing; as n. the beholding, sight; the becoming visible, 10320; appearance,  410. [√dṛś.]
1905: darśa-pūrṇa-māsá, dual m. new and full moon; the days and the festivals of new and full moon.
1906: dáśa [4834], num. ten. [cf. δέκα, Lat. decem, Goth. taihun, Eng. ten, Ger. zehn, ‘ten’; Eng. -teen in six-teen, etc.]
1907: daśamá, f. -ī́, a. tenth; daśamī́, sc. tithi, tenth day of a lunar half-month. [daśa, 4876.]
1908: daśa-śata, n. ten hundred; a thousand.
1909: dáśaśākha, a. having ten branches, i. e. fingers. [dáśa + śā́khā: acct, 1300a.]
1910: daśā, f. the threads projecting at the end of a weft, fringe; lamp-wick; fig. wick of life, course of life; time of life.
1911: daśāhá, m. space of ten days. [dáśa + 2 áha, 13124.]
1912: √das (dásyati; dadā́sa; ádasat; dastá; dāsáyati). suffer lack. [cf. √dās, dasyu: also δέω, ‘lack.’] + vi, become exhausted.
1913: dásyu, m. demon, foe of gods and men. [cf. √das, dāsá.]
1914: √dah (dáhati, -te; dadā́ha, dehé; ádhākṣīt; dhakṣyáti; dagdhá; dágdhum; dagdhvā́; -dáhya; dahyáte). 	—1. burn with fire; burn; 	—2. pass.: be burned; be pained or tortured; 	—3. dagdha, see s. v. [for *dhagh: cf. Goth. dags, AS. dœg, Eng. day, Old High Ger. tak, ‘day.’] + ā, in ādahana. + vi, injure by burning, 8417. + sam, consume.
1915: √1dā (dádāti, dádati [668]; dadaú, dadé; ádāt, ádita [884]; dāsyáti, -te; dattá [955c], -tta [1087c]; dā́tum; dattvā́; -dā́ya; dīyáte [770b]; dítsati [1030]; dāpáyati). give; bestow; grant; impart; w. acc. of thing and dat. or gen., later also loc., of person, 117, 2320, 2117; varaṃ dā, grant a wish; śāpaṃ dā, (give, i. e.) pronounce a curse; saubhāgyaṃ dā, (give, i. e.) wish conjugal felicity; dā, (give, i. e.) sell, w. instr. of price, 474; uttaraṃ dā, make answer; śrāddhaṃ dā, perform a śrāddha, 443, 10417; punar dā, give back; --desid. desire or be ready to give. [cf. δίδωμι, Lat. dă-re, ‘give.’] + anu, (like Ger. nach-geben, ‘yield,’ and so) grant, admit; ppl. ánutta [1087e], admitted. + ā, take (opp. of give), 2817; grasp, 706; ādāya, having taken, equiv. to with. + upa_ā, receive, appropriate. + pari, deliver over; commit; entrust. + pra, give; grant; impart (sciences); ppl. f. práttā [1087e], given in marriage, married.
1916: √2dā (dyáti [761d 3]; dadé; ádāt, ádita [884]; diná [957a], -tta [1087e]; -dā́ya; dīyáte). cut. [cf. √day, dāya.] + ava, cut off, esp. a part of the sacrificial cake; ppl. avatta [1087e], as subst. that which is cut off. + sam-ava, cut in pieces and collect them; ppl. samávatta, as subst. gathered pieces.
1920: dātṛ, m. giver; as a. [3753], generous, 214, 482. [√1dā.]
1921: dā́na, n. giving, imparting; gift. [√1dā, 1150: cf. Lat. dōnum, ‘gift.’]
1922: dāna-dharma, m. the virtuous practice of alms-giving.
1923: dānavá, m. child of Dānu, a Dānava, one of a class of demons, foes of the gods; Titan. [1dā́nu, 1208c.]
1924: 1dā́nu, f. Dānu, name of a demon, 7018.
1926: dānta, a. tamed, mild; subdued (as to one's passions); as subst. Dānta, name of a son of Bhīma. [ppl. of √dam, 955a.]
1931: 2dāyá, m. portion, inheritance. [√2dā: cf. δαίς, ‘portion, meal.’]
1935: dā́ru, n. wood; log or billet of wood; stick. [see the equiv. drú and taru: cf. δόρυ, ‘wood, beam, shaft’; δρῦς, ‘tree, oak’; Goth. triu, ‘wood, tree’; Eng. tree, ‘wood’ (so Wyclif), ‘a large woody plant’ (usual mg), ‘a wooden bar’ (in whiffle-tree).]
1937: √dāś (dā́śati; dadā́śa, dāśvā́ṃs [790b]). grant, offer; esp. serve or honor a god with offerings; dāśvā́ṃs, as subst. a pious servant of a god, 6911. [w. dadā́śa, cf. δέδωκα, ‘granted, gave’; ἔ-δωκ-α is an imperfect indicative without thematic vowel, corresponding to *á-dāś-am; but both Greek forms became connected in the popular mind with δίδωμι, ‘give.’]
1938: √dās (only with abhi, abhidā́sati). bear ill-will to; try to harm. [cf. √das, dasyu, dāsa.]
1939: dāsá, m. 	—1. foe; esp. supernatural foe, evil demon; 	—2. (in opp. to ārya) foe of the gods, infidel; used like Caffre and Giaour; 	—3. (subdued foe, i. e.) servant, slave, 792; --dāsī́, f. female slave. [√dās: cf. √das, dasyu.]
1940: dāsá-patnī, a. f. having the demon for their master. [acct, 1251b, 1295.]
1941: díti, f. Diti, name of a deity without definite character, a mere pendant to aditi as sura to asura, and formed by popular etymology as sura from asura. [see aditi and daitya.]
1942: didṛ́kṣu, a. desirous to see. [fr. desid. of √dṛś, 1178f: acct !]
1943: didyú, m. missile. [see √1dīv or dyū, and 1147b2.]
1944: didhiṣú, a. desirous to win; as m. suitor; husband; esp. second husband. [fr. desid. of √1dhā, 1178f, 1028d.]
1945: dína, 	—1. perhaps adj. clear, in su-dína; 	—2. as n. day. [perhaps ppl. of √dī or di, ‘shine,’ w. shifted acct.]
1946: dina-traya, n. day-triad, trīduum, space of three days.
1947: √div : there is no verbal root div in Sanskrit: cf. noun dív and √√1 and 2dīv or dīū.
1948: dív [361d], m. 	—1. sky, heaven, e. g. 722; 	—1a. Heaven, personified as Father, e. g. RV. vi. 51. 5; 	—1b. duhitā́ divás, of the Dawn, daughter of the sky or of Heaven, 7516; 	—2. day, e. g. 708, 7913; 	—3. observe that dív is sometimes fem. in Veda, so 921, 8, RV. x. 125. 7. [w. gen. div-ás, cf. the genitives Διός, *Διϝ-ός, Lat. Jŏv-is, and AS. Tiw-es in Tiwes dœg, Eng. Tues-day: (Tiw corresponds to the old Germanic Tiu, no longer a god of the sky or bright day, but rather a god of battle or fighting, the chief occupation of our early forefathers:) w. nom. dyaús, cf. •Δϳηύς: w. voc. dyau11ṣ pítar, cf. Ζεῦ πάτερ, Lat Jū-piter, ‘Heaven Father’: w. dúhitar divas, cf. θύγατερ Διός, ἄμβροτ᾽Ἀθάνα, Oedipus Rex 159: cf. also δῖος, ‘heavenly’; Lat. nom. Diovi-s, ‘god of heaven,’ Jŏv-em, ‘Jove’; sub dio, ‘under the sky’; Eng. Tewes-ley, ‘Tiw's lea,’ a place in Surrey.]
1949: divá, n. heaven; day, in divé-dive, day by day. [dív, 1209a.]
1950: dívā, adv. by day. [fr. the instr. div-ā́, w. shifted acct, 1112e.]
1951: divaukas, m. caelicola, god. [‘having heaven as a dwelling’: diva + okas.]
1953: √diś (diśáti; didéśa; ádikṣat, ádiṣṭa [883]; dekṣyáti; diṣṭá; déṣṭum; -díśya; diśyáte; deśáyati). point; direct; show. [cf. δείκνυμι, ‘show’; Lat. dīco, ‘show, tell’; AS. tāh, Ger. zieh, ‘pointed out (as guilty), accused’; Ger. zeigen, ‘show’; also AS. tāh-te, tǣh-te, Eng. taught, ‘showed, instructed’; AS. tācn, Eng. token.] + apa, show; make a false show of. + vy-apa, make a false show of. + ā, point out to, give a direction to, direct. + sam-ā, point out to, direct; command. + ud, point out; aim towards; uddiśya, w. acc., with an aiming towards, equiv. to the prep. at, 2622. + upa, show to, teach, instruct; give advice to, advise. + pra, point out, designate; direct.
1954: díś, f. just like Eng. point, i. e. cardinal point, quarter of the heaven (N., E., S., W.); aṣṭau diśas, eight regions (N., E., S., W., and NE., SE., SW., NW.), 5712. [√diś, ‘to point.’]
1955: √dih (dégdhi; didihé; digdhá; -díhya). 	—1. stroke, touch lightly; 	—2. smear; 	—3. besmear, pollute. [for *dhigh: cf. ἔθιγον, ‘touched’; Lat. fingo, ‘form, fashion,  esp. with the hand in soft material’; Goth. daigs, ‘moulded mass of clay or bread-paste’; Old Eng. dāg, Eng. dough.] + sam, pass. (be plastered together, be indistinct, and so) be uncertain, doubtful.
1957: √dīkṣ (dī́kṣate; didī́kṣa, didīkṣé; ádīkṣiṣṭa; dīkṣiṣyáte; dīkṣitá; dīkṣitvā́; -dī́kṣya). consecrate one's self, esp. for performing the Soma-sacrifice. [perhaps desid. of √dakṣ, ‘make one's self suitable or ready’: 108g.]
1958: dīti, f. glance, flame, actually occurring only in su-dītí. [√dī, 1157. 1a.]
1960: dīná, a. scanty; cast down, sad; wretched.
1962: dīnāra, m. denarius, name of a certain gold coin. [borrowed fr. Lat. dēnārius, a silver coin worth ten asses.]
1963: √dīp (dī́pyate; didīpé; dīptá; -dī́pya; dédīpti; dīpáyati, -te). blaze; flame; caus. kindle; intens. blaze brightly; fig. be radiant. [cf. √dī.] + ud, blaze up; caus. cause to blaze up.
1964: dīrghá, a. long, in space and in time; -am, as adv.; --comp. drā́ghīyāṃs, superl. drā́ghiṣṭha. [√drāgh: cf. δολιχός, ‘long.’]
1965: dīrgha-karṇa, m. Long-ear, name of a cat.
1966: dīrgha-rāva, m. Long-yell or Far-howl, name of a jackal. (Their howling is both long-continued and far-reaching.)
1968: dīrghavarṇānta, a. having a long vowel as final. [anta.]
1969: √1dīv (dī́vyati; didéva [2403]; ádevīt; deviṣyáti; dyūtá; dévitum; -dī́vya). dice; play. [prop. dīū, see 7651 and 2: orig., perhaps, ‘throw,’ cf. didyu.] + ā, in ādevana.
1970: √2dīv (dévati [2403]; dyūná [957a]; dévitum; deváyati, -te). lament. [prop. dīū, see 7651 and2.] + pari, moan, bemoan; caus. the same.
1971: duḥkhá, a. miserable; as n. misery, pain, sorrow. [cf. sukha.]
1973: ducchúnā, f. calamity; harm. [dus + śuna, ‘mis-fortune, ill-luck,’ 1683.]
1975: dur-, the form taken by dus before sonants.
1976: dur-atikrama, a. hard to overcome. [‘having a hard conquest,’ cf. 1304b.]
1978: dur-gá, a. whose going is hard, hard to go through or to, impassable; as n. difficult place; danger.
1981: dur-dānta, a. overcome with difficulty; as m. Hard-to-tame (Δυσνίκητος), name of a lion.
1982: dur-nivāra, a. whose warding-off is hard; hard to get rid of.
1983: dur-bala, a. of (poor, i. e.) little strength; feeble.
1984: durbuddhi, a. of (bad, i. e.) small wit; foolish.
1985: dur-bhága, a. ill-portioned, ill-favored; -ā, f. ugly woman. [acct, 1304b.]
1986: dur-bhikṣa, a. (time) having its alms-getting hard, i. e. in which alms-getting is hard; as n. famine. [bhikṣā.]
1987: dur-maṅgala, a. of bad luck, bringing bad luck.
1991: dur-vipāka, m. evil issue (of one's destiny).
1992: dur-vṛtta, a. of evil life, wicked.
1995: duvás, n. perhaps same as dúvas, but see 7410N.
1996: √duvasya (duvasyáti). reward with a gift; honor or worship (a god) with an offering. [dúvas.] + ā, perhaps bring or entice hither by worship, but see 7410N.
1998: duṣ-kara, a. whose performance is hard, hard to be performed. [dus.]
2000: duṣṭa, a. spoiled; bad, morally; cross. [ppl. of √duṣ.]
2001: dus, inseparable prefix, characterizing a thing as evil, bad, hard; forming w. action-nouns cpds w. the same mg as if compounded w. a future pass. ppl., e. g. duṣ-kara, ‘having its doing hard, i. e. difficult to be done.’ [cf. √duṣ: also δυς-, ‘mis-’. see 2252.]
2002: dus-tara, a. having its crossing hard, hard to cross.
2003: √duh (dógdhi, dugdhé; dudóha, duduhé; ádhukṣat, -ata [918]; dhokṣyáte; dugdhá; dógdhum; dugdhvā́; doháyati). 	—1. milk; then, generalized 	—2. get the good out of a thing; 	—3. extract; 	—4. give milk; 	—5. in general, give or yield any good thing, 8016; --caus., like simple, milk, extract. [for mg 2, cf. ἀμέλγεσθαί τινα, ‘milk a person dry.’] + nis, milk out of; extract from.
2005: duhitṛ́ [3733], f. daughter. [derivation uncertain, 1182d: cf. θυγάτηρ, Goth. dauhtar, Eng. daughter, Ger. Tochter, ‘daughter. ’]
2006: √1dū, subsidiary form of √1dā, in dúvas, duvasya. [cf. √√sthā and gā w. their equiv. collateral forms sthū and gū.]
2007: √2dū, go to a distance, in dūtá and dūrá. [cf. δεύομαι, ‘am at a distance from something,  fall short of.’]
2008: dūḍábha, a. hard to deceive. [‘whose deceiving is hard’: for duzdabha, i. e. dus + dabha, 199b3.]
2010: dūrá, a. far; as n. the distance; --caseforms as adverbs: -am, to a distance, far away; -e, in the distance, afar; at or from a distance; -āt, from afar. [√2dū, 1188.]
2011: dūrī-kṛ (dūrīkaroti). put far away; send off. [dūra, 1094.]
2014: √1dṛ (dṛṇā́ti; dadā́ra, dadré; ádārṣīt; dīrṇá; -dī́rya; dīryáte; dárdarti [1002b]; daráyati, dāráyati). burst, trans. and intrans.; --caus. and intens.: split; tear, w. gen. [cf. δέρω, δείρω, ‘flay’; AS. teran, Eng. tear, Ger. zerren, ‘tear, rend.’]
2015: √2dṛ (driyáte; ádṛta; dṛtá; -dṛ́tya). used only w. ā, see 773. [cf. √δελ in δεν-δίλλω, ‘glance at’; AS. tilian, 'be intent upon, attend to, esp. the earth, i. e. till (the soil),’ Eng. till; Ger. zielen, ‘aim at’; AS. eorð-tilia, ‘earth-tiller.’] + ā, (look at, i. e.) regard; pass. be regarded,  i. e. respected.
2017: dṛ́ti, m. bag of leather; bellows. [√1dṛ: for mg, cf. δέρμα, ‘skin bag or bottle.’]
2018: √dṛp (dṛ́pyati; ádṛpat; darpiṣyáti, drapsyáti; dṛptá; darpáyati). be crazed, wild, proud, insolent, or arrogant.
2020: √dṛś (dadárśa, dadṛśé; ádrākṣīt, ádṛṣṭa; drakṣyáti, -te; dṛṣṭá; dráṣṭum; dṛṣṭvā́; -dṛ́śya; dṛśyáte; dídṛkṣate; darśáyati). see; behold; --pass. be seen; be or become visible; appear; --caus. cause (a person, acc., 333) to see (a thing, acc., 336, 357, 367); show (w. gen. 632); w. ātmānam, show one's self, appear, pretend to be (e. g. frightened, 414). [present forms supplied by √1paś, q. v.: w. dadárśa, cf. δέδορκε, ‘saw’: cf. Goth. ga-tarh-jan, ‘make a show of.’] + prati, pass. appear over against one or before one's eyes. + vi, pass. be seen far and wide. + sam, behold; caus. show; w. ātmānam, show one's self, appear, pretend to be (e. g. dead).
2021: dṛ́ś [2183, dṛk, dṛśam, dṛgbhyām], 	—1. vbl. seeing, looking; --2. as f. the seeing; dṛśé, as inf. [970a], for beholding; --3. in cpds [518], look, appearance. [√dṛś.]
2022: dṛśa, m. the seeing; in cpds [518], look, appearance. [do.]
2023: dṛśí, f. the seeing; dṛśáye, as inf. [970f], for beholding. [do.]
2024: dṛ́śya, grdv. to be seen; worthy to be seen, splendid. [√dṛś, 963d.]
2025: dṛṣád, f. stone; esp. nether mill-stone.
2026: dṛṣad-upalā́, dual f. the nether and the upper mill-stone. [1253a, 1258.]
2028: dṛṣṭa-pūrva, a. seen previously. [equiv. to pūrvaṃ dṛṣṭa, see 1291.]
2029: dṛ́ṣṭi, f. 	—1. seeing; 	—2. sense of sight; 	—3. glance, look; 	—4. view. [√dṛś: cf. δέρξις, ‘sense of sight.’]
2030: √dṛh (dṛ́ṃhati, -te [mg 1, cf. 758]; dṛ́hyati, -te [mg 2, see 767]; ádṛṃhīt; dṛḍhá [224a]; dṛṃháyati). 	—1. act. make firm or steady or enduring; establish; mid. be firm; dṛḍhá [1176a], firm; 	—2. be firm; 	—3. caus. make stable. [cf. Old Lat. forc-tis, Lat. fortis, ‘strong.’]
2032: déya, grdv. to be given or granted. [√dā, 963a.]
2033: devá, f. devī́, 	—1. a. heavenly, 7414, 16, 18, 927; as subst. 	—2. god, goddess; 	—2a. pl. the gods (in later times reckoned as 33, cf. tridaśa); 	—2b. víśve devā́s, all the gods; also all-gods (a term comprehending into a class all the separate gods, cf. All-saints, and see viśvádeva); 	—2c. devī́, The Goddess,  i. e. Śiva's wife, Durgā; 	—2d. -deva, at end of Brahman-names, having…as god, so, e. g., guṇadeva; --3. m. manuṣya-deva, god among men, i. e. a Brahman, see 951; similarly, 	—4. m. king, 1912, 504, 514, 7, 14; so used of a lion (3215) or even of a jackal (3621); f. queen. 2034: devá-kāma, a. having love for the gods. [acct, 12932, 1295.]
2035: devátā, f. godhead or divinity, both as abstract and as concrete; devátā, instr., with divinity (collective), i. e. among deities, 7320 [1237.]
2037: deva-dūtá, m. messenger of the gods.
2038: deva-daivatya, a. having the gods as divinity, (of hymns) addressed to the gods.
2039: deva-pati, m. lord of the gods, i. e. Indra.
2040: deva-pā́na, a. serving the gods for drinking. [lit. ‘god-drenching, i. e. gotttränkend’: acct, 1271, 1251c.]
2041: deva-yā́na, n. path of the gods, on which the intercourse between gods and men takes place. [acct, 1271, 1251c.]
2043: deva-rājá, m. king of the gods, i. e. Indra. [rājan, 1315a.]
2044: deva-liṅga, n. god-characteristic, mark by which a god may be distinguished from a man.
2045: deva-śarman, m. Devaśarman or God'sjoy,  name of a certain Brahman. [of like mg is θεό-χαρις.]
2046: deva-saṃnidhi, m. presence of the gods.
2047: devá-hūti, f. invocation of the gods. [acct, 1274.]
2050: devī-koṭṭa, m. Goddess-fort, name of a town.
2051: devī-vinirmita, a. laid out by Durgā. [√1mā.]
2052: devṛ́ [3692], m. husband's brother. [cf. δαήρ, Lat. lēvir, ‘husband's brother.’]
2053: deśá, m. 	—1. (point, i. e.) place, 4118; 	—2. country, 245, see 9816N.; 	—3. place, pregnantly, as in Eng., i. e. proper place, 225; 	—4. as in Eng., place or region of the body, see muṣka-, skandha-. [√diś, ‘point.’]
2054: deśa-bhāṣā, f. dialect of the country.
2055: deṣṭṛ, m. pointer, guide, instructor; f. déṣṭrī, Instructress, as a deity, 909. [√diś, 1182: cf. *δεικτηρ in δεικτήριος, ‘pertaining to one who shows.’]
2056: deha, m. n. body; mentioned w. manas and vāc, 659. [√dih, ‘stroke lightly so as to mould or form,’ and so, prob. ‘the figure, form, shape,’ like the Lat. figūra, ‘shape, form,’ from the cognate √fig, fingo: see √dih.]
2057: dehin, a. connected with the body, 6511; as m. a living being, man. [deha, 1230.]
2058: daitya, m. descendant of Diti, q. v.; a Daitya or demon. [díti, 1211.]
2059: daitya-dānava-mardana, m. Daitya-andDānava-crusher,  epithet of Indra.
2060: daiva, a. of the gods, 5721; coming from the gods; divine; as n. divine appointment,  i. e. fate, 1812, etc. [devá, 1208f.]
2061: daivata, a. pertaining to a divinity; as n. 	—1. a divinity or, collectively, the divinities,  esp. that or those celebrated in any Vedic hymn; 	—2. idol, 6218. [devatā, 1208e.]
2062: daivatya, at end of cpds, having…as divinity, addressed to…, 635. [devatā, 1211.]
2063: daivika, a. of the gods; divine. [deva, 1222e.]
2064: daívya, a. of the gods; divine. [devá, 1211.]
2065: dola, m. a swinging; f. dolā, a dooly (Anglo-Indian term), a little bamboo chair slung on four men's shoulders. [√dul.]
2067: dolāyamāna-mati, a. having a wavering mind. [√dolāya.]
2068: 1doṣa, m. 	—1. fault, defect; bad condition,  555; 	—2. sin, transgression, fault, 118, 1817, 6521; doṣam avāp, incur a transgression, 684; 	—3. harm; evil consequence;  doṣeṇa, doṣāt, by or as a bad consequence of, by, faute de, 2321, 352. [√duṣ.]
2069: 2doṣa, m. evening, dark; f. dosā́, evening, dark.
2070: doṣā-vastṛ, m. illuminer of the darkness;  or, as adj. [cf. 3753], lighting up in the dark.
2072: dyā́vā-pṛthivī́, dual f. heaven and earth. [dív + pṛthivī́, 1255 and a2.]
2074: √dyut (dyótate; didyuté; ádyutat; dyotiṣyáti; dyuttá; -dyútya). gleam; lighten; shine. [akin w. noun dív, q. v.: cf. also √jyut.] + vi, lighten.
2079: dráviṇa, n. movable property (as opp. to house and field), wealth. [√dru, 1177b.]
2080: dravya, n. 	—1. property; 	—2. in general, thing, object; 	—3. esp. worthy object. [√dru: see draviṇa.]
2082: √1drā (drā́ti; dadraú; ádrāsīt; intens. [1002c, 10242] daridrāti). run; intens. run about, run hither and thither. [cf. δι-δρά-σκω, ‘run’: see √dru.] + apa, run off. [cf. ἀπο-δρᾶναι, ‘run off.’]
2083: √2drā (drā́ti; drā́yate; dadraú; ádrāsīt; drāsyáti; drāṇá). sleep. [cf. ἔδραθον, ‘slept’; Lat. dormīre, ‘sleep.’] + ni, go to sleep; sleep.
2084: √drāgh, only in derivs. drag, draw; draw out; extend; lengthen. [poss. for *dhragh (cf. √dhraj), and akin w. Eng. drag: but see dīrghá.]
2085: drā́ghīyāṃs, a. longer, as comp. to dīrghá. [√drāgh, 467.]
2086: √dru (drávati, -te; dudrā́va, dudruvé; ádudruvat [868]; droṣyáti; drutá; drótum; drutvā́; -drútya). hasten; run; run away, flee, 947. [ident. w. √dram, ‘run,’ and w. √1drā, q. v.: cf. ἔδρᾰμε and ἔδρᾱ, ‘ran.’] + ati, run past or by; escape. + ā, run unto, make an attack, charge, 945, 6. + upa, run unto. + sam-upa, run unto, rush at, 312.
2089: druta, ppl. having hastened [9522]; -am, as adv. hastily, rapidly; quickly; immediately.  [√dru.]
2090: druma, m. tree. [drú: cf. δρῡμός, ‘a wood.’]

2103: dvāra-pakṣa, m. side of the door.

2105: dvi-já, a. twice-born; as m. member of one of the three upper castes, re-born by virtue of investiture (see √nī + upa), 602, 5820, 594, 627; in a narrower sense, a Brahman,  2114, 434, 559, 6416.

2114: dvi-pada, f. -ī, a. having (taken) two steps.
2115: dvi-pravrājin, f. -nī, a. in f. going after two (men), unchaste, 9814.
2116: √dviṣ (dvéṣṭi, dviṣṭé; didvéṣa; ádvikṣat, -ata; dviṣṭá; dvéṣṭum). hate; show hatred; be hostile. [cf. ὀ-δύσ-αντο, ‘became wroth,’ w. prothetic ο.]
2117: dvíṣ, vbl. hating, in cpds; as f. hate; as m. concrete, hater, foe. [√dviṣ.]
2118: dvís, adv. twice. [see dvi, dva: cf. δίς, Lat. bis, *dvis, ‘twice’: the radically cognate Eng. twice is a gen. form.]

2123: dvedhā́, adv. in two, in two kinds. [for *dvayadhā, fr. dvaya, 11042.]
2125: dvéṣas, n. hatred; concrete, hater, foe. [√dviṣ.]
2126: dha, vbl. bestowing, granting, in vasu-dha. [√1dhā, 333.]
2128: dhána, n. 	—1. the prize of the contest; not only the reward put up for the victor, but also the booty taken from the foe--Vedic; so w. √ji, win booty by conquest, 812; then, 	—2. in general, wealth, riches, property, money. [√dhā, ‘put’: cf. θέμα, ‘thing put up as a prize,’ and for the mg also Ger. Ein-satz, ‘stakes.’]
2129: dhanu, m. bow. [fr. dhanus, a transfer to the u-declension.]
2130: dhanuṣ-kāṇḍa, n. bow and arrow. [dhanus: see 1253b.]
2133: √dhanv (dhánvati; dadhanvé; ádhanvīt ). set in motion; run. [secondary form of √dhan.]
2135: dhanvin, a. subst. having a bow, bowman.  [dhanvan, 1230b.]
2136: √dham or dhmā (dhámati [750]; dadhmaú; ádhmāsīt; dhamiṣyáti; dhamitá, dhmātá; -dhmā́ya). blow, breathe out; blow (pipe, shell, bag-pipe, bellows). [see 108g and 750.] + ā, blow up; ādhmāta, fig. puffed up.
2137: dhara, a. holding; bearing; keeping; wearing. [√dhṛ.]
2138: dhárma, m. 	—1. custom, 9816; usage, 9911; right; duty, 286; virtue, 217, 1013, 1517, 291; (virtue, i. e.) good works, 295, 6311; correct course of conduct, 113; dharme, in a question of right, 2114; 	—1a. dharmeṇa, adv.: as was right, 1417; dutifully, 165; 	—2. law; prescription, rule; the law (as a system), 285, 5816, 19; 	—3. personified, Virtue, 6717, 484. [a post-Vedic word, taking the place of V. dhárman: dharma is fr. √dhṛ (1166b), perhaps in mg 6, and thus designating ancient custom or right as ‘that which holds its own, which persists or endures’; but it may come fr. √dhṛ in mg 1, so that dharma is ‘that which is established or settled’; in the latter case, cf., for the mg, θέμις, ‘that which is established as custom or law,’ w. τίθημι, ‘set, establish,’ and Ger. Ge-setz, ‘law,’ w. setzen, ‘set.’]
2139: dharma-jña, a. knowing the law or one's duty or what is right.
2140: dharma-jñāna, n. knowledge of the law.
2141: dharmatas, adv. in a way which starts from dharma, i. e. in accordance with good usage, 5919; by rights, 6116. [dharma, 1098c3.]
2142: dhárman, n. established ordinance; steadfast decree (e. g. of a god), 8010; dhármaṇā, according to the established order of things, in a way that accords with nature, 848. [√dhṛ, 1168. 1c: see under dharma.]
2143: dharma-mūla, n. the root or foundation of the law.
2144: dharma-víd [391], a. knowing the law or one's duty, 115; acquainted with good usage, 6110.
2145: dharma-śāstra, n. authoritative or canonical compend of dharma, 5818; lawbook;  law-shaster.
2146: dharmātman, a. having virtue or right as one's nature; just. [ātman.]
2149: √1dhā (dádhāti, dhatté [668]; dadhaú, dadhé; ádhāt, ádhita [884]; dhāsyáti, -te; V. -dhita, later hitá [954c]; dhā́tum; dhitvā́; -dhā́ya; dhīyáte; dídhiṣati, dhítsati; dhāpáyati [1042d]). 	—1. put, 8610; set; lay, 3914; 	—2. put in a place, bring to, w. tatra, 8519; w. loc., 898, 955; w. dat., 831; 	—3. put upon, direct towards; dharme dhā manas, set the heart on virtue, 667; 	—4. put something for a person (dat.), i. e. bestow upon him, grant him, 841, RV. x. 125. 2; 	—5. put in a position, i. e. appoint, constitute, w. double acc., 8812; 	—6. make, cause, produce; 	—7. hold, keep, 866, 9; 	—8. mid. take to one's self, receive, obtain, win; esp. garbhaṃ dhā, conceive fruit in the womb, 9212; 	—9. mid. assume, 197; maintain; 	—10. hita, see s. v.; 	—11. desid. act. desire to grant; mid. desire to win. [The original meaning of the root is ‘put’; but, from the proethnic period, a secondary development in the line (‘set,’ ‘establish,’ and so) ‘make,’ ‘do,’ is clear. The secondary mg has even won the more prominent place in Germanic and Slavic. For the primary mg, cf. τίθημι, ‘put’ (the parallelism of its mgs is remarkable --θέσαν, λίθον, ‘they set a stone’; θέσθαι υἱόν, ‘conceive a son,’ etc., etc.); Lat. abde-re, ‘put off or away,’ and con-de-re, ‘put together, construct, establish’; Eng. do, ‘put,’ in the contract forms doff, don, dup; Ger. weg-thun, ‘do away or put away.’ For the secondary mg, cf. θεῖναί τινα βασιλέα, ‘make one a king’; AS. dōn hine tō cyninge, ‘make him a king’; Lat. fīo, ‘am made’; Eng. do, deed; Ger. thun, ‘do’; Slavic dĕ-lo, ‘deed’: observe that fi-eri, ‘become,’ is to fă-c-ere, ‘make,’ as ī-re (√ja), ‘go,’ is to jă-c-ere, ‘make to go, throw.’] + antar, 	—1. put into the interior of a thing; and so 	—2. hide, conceal. + api, put close upon; cover (a jar with its lid); ápihita, closed up. [cf. ἐπιτίθημι, ‘put upon.’] + abhi, put on; put a name upon, designate;  address; speak to, 4310; say, 4220; abhihitam, (it was) said, 3813. + ava, put down in; esp. duck (trans.) into the water; ávahita, fallen into the water; caus. cause to be laid in. + ā, 	—1. put or lay or set in or on, w. loc., 771, 7912, 8815, 905, 10221; 	—2. put on (wood on the fire), 8215; 	—3. mid. set for one's self on (the hearth a sacred fire), 9512; 	—4. mid. put on one's self, take on, 746; 	—5. take, i. e. take away, 8710. + vy-ā, pass. be separated; be uncomfortable or sick. + sam-ā, put upon; w. manas, concentrate the mind upon one thing; samāhita, intent, eager, 113. + upa-sam-ā, set together (wood) unto (an already burning fire), put (fuel) on, 10016, 10510. + upa, put on (esp. a brick or stone on the sacred fire-altar or enclosure), 968 ff. + ni, lay down, 878; set down (sacred fire), 856; w. kriyām, put labor upon (loc.), take pains with, 1914; nihita, put down, lying low, 7019. + saṃ-ni, lay down together; put together;  pass. be near together; saṃnihita, near, impending, 2515. + pari, put around; esp. put (part of a sacrificial fence) around (an altar), 10513; put around one's self, put on, (garments) 10319, (shoes) 4511; clothe. + puras, see s. v. + pra, set forward. [cf. pradhana, pradhāna. ] + vi, 	—1. part, mete out, distribute; 	—2. spread abroad, RV. x. 125. 3; 	—3. (like Lat. dis-pōnere) arrange, determine; prescribe,  597; vihita, ordained, 144; 	—4. lay out, make, build; prepare, 5418; 	—5. accomplish,  5612; make, do (in a great variety of applications); vadhaṃ vidhā, do slaughter, slay, 3214; pūjāṃ vidhā, do or show honor, 2813; pravṛttiṃ vidhā, make an advance into, w. loc., expose one's self to, 2012; upāyaṃ vidhā, employ an expedient, 392; kiṃ vidheyam, what's to be done, 315; tathā vidhīyatām, so let it be done, 114; yathā…, tan mayā vidheyam, I must take such a course, that…, 376; cf. 3822. + śrad, see śrad. + sam, put together, unite; embroil in, w. loc., 7314.
2150: √2dhā (dháyati [761d 2]; dadhaú; ádhāt; dhāsyáti; dhītá; dhā́tum; -dhī́ya; dhītvā́ ). suck; drink, 631. [cf. dadhi, dhenu: also θήσατο, ‘sucked’; γαλα-θηνός, ‘milksucking’;  θη-λή, ‘breast’; Lat. fē-lare, ‘suck’; Goth. dadd-jan, ‘give suck.’]

2154: dhātṛ́, m. establisher; creator; Dhātar, as name of a deity, 909N. [√1dhā.]

2173: 2dhīra, a. firm; resolute, 482. [√dhṛ: cf. Lat. fir-mus, ‘firm.’]

2176: √dhū (dhūnóti, -nuté; later, dhunóti, -nuté [see 711]; dudhā́va, dudhuvé; ádhūṣṭa [887a]; dhaviṣyáti; dhūtá, later dhutá; dhūtvā́; -dhū́ya). 	—1. move quickly hither and thither; shake; 	—2. fan (a fire); 	—3. shake off. 2177: dhūmá, m. smoke; vapor. [cf. Lat. fūmus, ‘smoke’: smoke has no such “swift eddying motion” as to make it easy to connect these names for it w. √dhū, q. v.; but on this connection their identification w. θῡμός should seem to depend: more prob. is the explanation of dhūmá as ‘the enveloping or blackening,’ fr. √1dhvan, as vāma fr. √van.]
2178: dhūmaka, m. smoke, at end of cpds [1307] for dhūma; f. -ikā [1222d], the same.

Middle Eng. schrewen, ‘curse,’ whence schrew-ed, ‘cursed, bad,’ Eng. shrewd, ‘bad, artful.’]
2180: dhūrta-traya, n. rogue-triad, trio of swindlers.
2181: dhūsara, a. dusted over, dusty, dust-colored,  gray. [√dhvaṃs, dhvas, 1188d: cf. 181a.]
2182: √dhṛ (dādhā́ra [786], dadhré; ádhṛta; dhariṣyáti, -te; dhṛtá; dhártum; dhṛtvā́; -dhṛ́tya; dhāráyati; ádīdharat). mgs of caus. forms ident. [10412] w. those of simple forms; hold, in its various mgs, trans. and intrans.; trans. 	—1. hold, bear, support, 3311, 393, 756, 7, 879, 921; make firm, 9210; carry, 6212; wear; 	—2. hold fast, 2210, 331; hold in check, bear, withstand, 220, 812; 	—3. keep (a cat), 319; 	—4. set or lay or place in or on, w. loc., 3312, 4121; 	—5. hold or make sure or ordain for some one (dat.); mid. be ordained for some one (dat.), belong of right to, 753; intrans. 	—6. mid. hold, i. e. remain, continue;  w. this mg, even in the active, 155. [cf. θρό-νος, ‘support, seat,’ θρᾶ-νος, ‘bench,’ θρή-σασθαι, ‘sit’; Lat. frē-tus, ‘held or supported by (hence w. abl.), relying on,’ frē-num, ‘holder, bridle.’] + ava, caus. 	—1. set down, fix; 	—2. (like Eng. hold) assume as certain, 4414.
2183: √dhṛṣ (dhṛṣṇóti; dadhárṣa; ádhṛṣat; dhṛṣitá, dhṛṣṭá; -dhṛ́ṣya; dharṣáyati). be bold or courageous; dare; venture, 742; --caus. venture on some one or something; offend; overpower; dharṣitá, overcome. 2189: √dhyā (dhyā́ti, dhyā́yati [761d 1]; dadhyaú; ádhyāsīt [911]; dhyāsyáti; dhyātá; dhyātvā́; -dhyā́ya). think upon; meditate. [see √dhī and 108g.] + abhi, set the mind on something; sink one's self in thought, 571.
2191: dhyāna-para, a. having meditation as highest object, absorbed in contemplation.  [1302b.]
2192: √dhraj (dhrájati; ádhrājīt). draw onward,  advance, intrans. [see √drāgh, of which this is poss. a collateral form.]

2196: dhruvā́, f. sacrificial ladle, 10213, see srúc. [lit. ‘holder,’ √dhṛ in mg 1: see 1190.]
2197: √dhvaṃs or dhvas (dhváṃsati, -te; dadhváṃsa, dadhvasé; ádhvasat; dhvastá; -dhvásya). 	—1. fall to dust, perish; dhvasta, exhausted, hurt, impaired; 	—2. vanish, be off; 	—3. only in ppl. dhvasta, bestrewn, covered over, esp. with dust. [cf. Eng. dus-t; prob. also AS. dwǣs and dysig, ‘foolish,’ Eng. dizzy, Old High Ger. tusīc, ‘foolish.’]
2199: √1dhvan (ádhvanīt; dhvāntá; dhvanáyati ). 	—1. cover one's self; dhvānta, dark; 	—2. become extinguished; --caus. 	—1. envelope, cover over; 	—2. blacken. [perhaps akin w. √dhvaṃs: see dhūma: cf. AS. dunn, Eng. dun, ‘dark, brownish-black. ’]
2200: √2dhvan (dhvánati; dadhvā́na; dhvāntá [955a]). sound, resound. [cf. Old Eng. dune, Eng. din.]
2202: √dhvṛ (dhvárati). bend or make crooked; cause to fall; harm by deceit. [see dhūrta and dhruti: cf. 2203: na [491], encl. pron. root of 1st person, see ahám. [w. nas, ‘us,’ cf. νώ, ‘we two,’ Lat. nōs, ‘us.’]
2204: ná, adv. 	—1. not [1122b], 32; 	—1a. in connected sentences or clauses: repeated simply: 978, octies; 6214, 15, quinquies; 6313, 14, 714, ter; 413, 1718, 741, 8017, bis; with ca: na…, na…ca, na ca…, 6216; na…, na ca…, na…, 631; with api: see api 2; with u, 2114; 	—1b. not repeated, but replaced by api ca or vā_api (see these), 212, 634; 	—1c. combinations: na ca, 816; na…ca, 137, 6216; naiva, 2219, 2319, 9610; na vai, 9215; na vā, 9612; na tu, 6413; na tv eva tu, see tu; na ha, 9517; na_iva, not exactly, 935; 	—1d. tantamount to a-in negative cpds [1122b4], as nacira, nātidūra, nādhīta, etc.; 	—1e. at beg. of adversative clause: with adversative conj., 3410; without, 2220, 4113, 9216; 	—1f. in emphatic litotes, 219; 	—1g. substantive verb to be supplied, 325 (asti); --1h. na precedes ced, if it belongs to the protasis, 639; if it immediately follows ced, it must be joined to the apodosis, 189; 	—1i. for prohibitive negative, see mā́; --1j. ná, ‘not,’ coalesces metrically in Veda w. following initial vowel, e. g. 7012, 714, 839; 	—2. like [see 1122d and d2], in this sense Vedic only, 7015, 18, 717, 9, etc.; ná, ‘like,’ does not coalesce metrically in Veda w. following initial vowel. [cf. νη-, Lat. nĕ-, negative prefix in νη-κερδές, ‘gain-less,’ nĕ-fas, ‘not right, wrong’; AS. and Old Eng. ne, ‘not’; AS. nā (ne + ā), ‘not ever, never, no,’ Eng. no; Eng. na- in nathless, AS. nā ϸē lœs, ‘not the less’; Eng. n- in n-ever, n-aught, etc.]

2217: √nad (nádati; nanā́da, nedé; naditá; -nádya). sound; roar; bellow. [see 1nadá and nadī́.]

2220: nadī́, f. roaring stream; river. [√nad: cf. Νέδα, Νέδων, names of streams.]
2222: √nand (nándati, -te; nanánda; nandiṣyáte; nanditá; -nándya). be glad. + abhi, be glad in; greet joyfully.
2223: nandana, a. gladdening; causing joy; as m. son, 2117; as n. Nandana, or Elysium, the pleasure ground of the gods, esp. of Indra, 4918. [caus. of √nand.]
2224: nandi, m. The Gladsome One, euphemistic epithet of the dreadful god, ŚivaRudra.  [√nand: cf. śiva.]
2225: nandi-deva, m. Nandideva, name of a Brahman. [‘having Śiva as his god.’]
2226: nápāt, náptṛ [370], m. 	—1. in Veda, descendant in general; son; grandson, 8718; 	—2. in Skt., grandson, 639. [declension: in Veda, nápāt, nápātam, náptrā, náptṛbhis, etc.; in Skt., náptā, náptāram, náptrā, náptṛbhis, etc.: see 1182d: cf. νέποδες, ‘young ones’; Lat. nepōtem, ‘grandson’; AS. nefa, ‘son's son or brother's son’--supplanted by Old French neveu (Eng. nephew), which in Old Eng. meant ‘son's son’ as well as ‘brother's son.’]
2227: naptī́ [356], f. daughter, 726; granddaughter.  [f. to nápāt: acct, 355b.]
2229: nábhas, n. 	—1. mist, clouds; 	—2. atmosphere,  sky. [cf. νέφος, νεφέλη, ‘cloud, mist’; Lat. nūbes, ‘cloud,’ nebula, ‘mist’; AS. nifol, ‘misty, gloomy’; Ger. Nebel, ‘mist’: for mg 2, cf. Ger. Wolken and AS. wolcnu, ‘clouds,’ w. Eng. welkin, ‘sky.’]
2230: nabhas-tala, n. sky-surface, i. e. sky, see tala.
2231: √nam (námati, -te; nanā́ma, nemé [794e]; ánaṃsīt; naṃsyáti; natá [954d]; námitum, nántum; natvā́; -námya; namáyati ). bow (intrans.), bend one's self; aim at a person (gen.) with (instr.), 7315; nata, bowed down, bending over, 6819N.; --caus. cause to bow, subdue; namyate, is subdued,  316. + ava, bow down, 3417. + ā, bow down to. + ud, raise one's self up, arise. + sam-ud, rise. + nis, bend out; contort one's self. + pra, make obeisance before (acc.).
2232: námas, n. bow, obeisance; adoration (by gesture or word); reverence; used also like the Lat. gloria in the Gloria patri. [√nam.]
2233: namas-kārá, m. a making of namas; adoration. [1713.]
2236: námuci, m. Namuchi, name of a demon, foe of Indra, 8116, 976.
2237: nayana, n. eye. [‘leader, organ of sense that leads,’ √nī, 1150. 1a: for mg, cf. ānana, gātra, caraṇa, netra.]
2238: nára, m. man, 321, etc.; at 575, the primal man or spirit. [transition-stem fr. nṛ, 1209a.]
2240: nara-pati, m. lord of men; king.
2241: nara-vāhana, a. subst. having men as his team, drawn by men; epithet and name of Kuvera, god of wealth; name of a king, successor of Śālivāhana.
2242: naravāhana-datta, m. Naravāhanadatta,  name of a son of king Udayana.
2244: naravāhanadattacaritamaya, f. -ī, a. containing the adventures of N. [1225: see maya.]
2245: nara-vyāghra, m. man-tiger, i. e. brave and noble man. [cf. naraśārdūla: 1280b.]
2246: nara-śārdūla, m. man-tiger, i. e. best among men. [cf. naravyāghra: 1280b.]
2247: nara-śreṣṭha, a. subst. best of men.
2248: nara-sūnu, f. daughter of the primal man or spirit.
2249: narādhipa, m. lord of men, i. e. king, prince. [adhipa.]
2250: nareśvara, m. lord of men, i. e. king, prince. [īśvara.]
2251: narottama, a. subst. best of men. [uttama. ]
2252: narmada, a. granting or causing fun; making gladness; f. -dā, Narmadā (called also Revā), the modern Nerbudda river. [narman + da.]
2254: nala, m. reed; Nala, name of a prince of Nishadha. [cf. naḍá, Vedic naḻá.]
2256: 1náva, a. new; of an earthen dish, (fresh, i. e.) unburned. [prob. fr. nú, ‘now,’ q. v.: cf. νέος, Lat. novus, Ger. neu, Eng. new.]
2257: 2náva [4834], num. nine. [cf. ἐννέα, Lat. novem, Ger. neun, Eng. nine.]
2259: náva-nīta, n. fresh butter. [perhaps ‘fresh-brought,’ as we say ‘bring the butter,  i. e. make it come,’ in churning.]
2260: návedas, a. perhaps well-knowing, cognizant of (gen.). [apparently fr. an affirmative particle na-, and vedas: see 12963 end.]
2261: √1naś (náśyati; nanā́śa, neśús; ánaśat; naṅkṣyáti [936]; naṣṭá; nāśáyati). be missing; get lost; vanish; perish, be ruined. [cf. νεκ-ρός, ‘dead’; Lat. nex, ‘death’; nocēre, ‘harm.’] + vi, get lost; perish; caus. cause to disappear;  bring to nought, 8120.
2262: √2naś (náśati, -te; nanā́śa; ā́naṭ [833]). attain; reach, come up to, 741; w. acchā, draw hither, 7611. [see √1aś, ‘reach’: cf. Lat. nac-tus sum, ‘am having reached’; AS. neāh, comp. neār, superl. neāhst, Eng. nigh, near (as comp., Macbeth ii. 3. 146), next; AS. ge-neah, ‘it reaches, es reicht, it suffices’; ge-nōh, Eng. e-nough.] + pra, reach to, hit; fall upon, 788.
2263: nás [397], f. nose. [nom. dual, nā́sā: cf. Lat. nas-turcium, ‘nose-teaser, nasturtium’; nār-es, ‘nostrils’; AS. nosu, Eng. nose; nos-tril, ‘nose-thrill, nose-hole.’]
2264: nas [491], encl. pron. form of 1st pers. [cf. νώ, ‘we two’; Lat. nōs, ‘us.’] nasa, for nás in cpds [1315c].
2265: √nah (náhyati [761c]; naddhá [2238]; -náhya). bind; join. [despite naddha (a poss. false formation), and Avestan nazda (Morphologische Untersuchungen, iii. 144), probably for *nagh: cf. Lat. nec-t-ere, ‘bind.’] + upa, tie on, lace.
2266: nahí, adv. not, to be sure; nahí me ásti, to be sure, I have no…. [ná + hí, 1122a and b4: acct of verb, 595d.]
2267: náhuṣa, m. Nahusha, name of an ancient king. [perhaps ‘neighbor,’ from náhus, and in that case a transfer-form (1209b).]
2269: nā́ka, m. vault of heaven, firmament.
2270: nātidūra, a. not very far. [na + atidūra, 1122b4.]
2271: √nāth (nā́thate; nāthitá; nā́thitum; -nā́thya). turn with supplication to.
2272: nāthá, n. a refuge; as m. protector; lord. [√nāth.]
2274: nā́bhi, f. 	—1. navel; 	—2. nave or hub. [cf. ὀμφ-αλός, Lat. umb-ilīcus, AS. naf-ela, Eng. navel; also AS. naf-u, Eng. nave.]
2275: nābhi-vardhana, n. the cutting of the navel(-string).
2276: nāma-dhéya, n. the name-giving, naming,  599; name, 179, 6022. [nāman.]
2277: nā́man, n. 	—1. distinguishing characteristic;  form; 	—2. name, 138, 6021b, 789, 619; nāma grah, (take i. e.) mention the name, 6413; personal name (e. g. devadatta ), as distinguished from the gotra or ‘family name’ (e. g. kāśyapa, ‘descendant of Kaśyapa’), 10319N.; at end of cpds, having…as name, named…, so 11 times, e. g. 1911; 	—3. nāma, adv. [1111b], by name, so 19 times, e. g. 13, 6021a, 9416; also nāmnā, 565; w. interrogatives, pray, 5416. [origin unknown: cf. ὄ-νομα, Lat. nōmen, Eng. name.]
2278: nārá, 	—1. a. human; 	—2. as m. man; --nā́rī, f. woman, 19, 8618, etc.; wife. [nṛ, 1208b: for mg 2, cf. mānava.]
2279: nārada, m. Nārada, name of an ancient devarṣi (see note to 114), who often appears on the earth to bring news from the gods, and returns to heaven with reports from men.
2280: nārāyaṇá, m. Nārāyana, son of the primal man. [simply a patronymic of nara, see 1219.]
2281: nāvā́, f. ship. [transfer-form (1209, 399) fr. nau, nāv.]
2283: nā́sā, dual f. the two nostrils, the nose. [transfer-form (399) fr. nás, strong nā́s.]
2284: nā́sikā, f. nostril; dual, the two nostrils; the nose. [nā́sā, 1222c 1.]
2285: nāstika, a. subst. atheist, infidel, not believing the Vedas and Purānas. [fr. na + asti, ‘there is not,’ 1314b.]
2286: nāhuṣa, m. descendant of Nahusha, patronymic of Yayāti. [náhuṣa, 1208 and f.]
2287: ní, prep. down; in, into. [cf. ἐνί, ‘in’; Eng. ne-ther, be-nea-th.]
2288: nikaṭa, a. near; as n. neighborhood; presence. [1245g.]
2289: nikhila, a. entire; all. [perhaps for niḥ-khila, ‘without a gap,’ nis + khila: 13052 end.]
2290: nijá, a. own; belonging to our party, 246; nijo ripus, foe in one's own camp, 3715; often used as reflexive possessive pron., my own, his own, our own, etc., --or rather, my (4717), his (5014, 5312, 564, 6), etc. [perhaps ‘in-born,’ fr. ni + ja.]
2291: niṇyá, a. inner; hidden, 7020; as n. secret, 783. [ni.]
2292: nítya, a. 	—1. own (Vedic), 7916; 	—2. constant;  eternal, 577; -am, adv. constantly, always, 1716, 6419. [in mg 1, fr. ni, ‘in,’ 1245b, and so signifying ‘inward, not alien.’]
2293: nitya-kāla, m. uninterrupted time; -am, adv. always, under all circumstances, 606.
2294: nitya-snāyin, a. constantly making sacred ablutions. [1279.]
2295: √nid or nind (níndati; ninínda; ánindīt; ninditá; -níndya). blame; reproach. [cf. ὄνειδος, ‘reproach.’]
2297: nidhána, m. n. end; death, 519. [perhaps fr. √dhā + ni, ‘put down or out of the way,’ ‘make an end of.’]
2300: nibandhana, n. a binding, ligation, 593; that on which a thing is fastened or rests or depends, condition, means, 467. [√bandh + ni.]
2301: nibhṛta, a. (borne down, lowered, i. e.) hidden; -am, adv. secretly. [√bhṛ + ni.]
2303: nimitta, n. mark (for shooting at); sign, token; occasion or cause; -am, -ena, adverbially, because of; tannimittam, -ena, because of this, on account of this.
2304: nimeṣá, m. closing or winking of the eyes. [√miṣ + ni.]
2305: niyoga, m. a fastening on; injunction, and so, commission; business, 306. [√yuj + ni: for mg, cf. alicui injungere laborem, ‘fasten or impose a task on a person.’]
2306: nir, for nis before sonants [174]; see nis.
2307: nir-antara, a. without interval or free space; completely filled, 5310; continuous; uninterrupted, 5612.
2308: nir-apāya, a. without failure or danger; infallible or safe.
2309: nir-apekṣa, a. without regard or expectation;  regardless, 5220; not expecting anything from another, independent, 3117. [apekṣā, 3342.]
2311: nir-āhāra, a. without food, abstaining from food.
2312: nír-ukta, a. spoken out; loud; clear; as n. explanation; etymological interpretation of a word; esp. Nirukta, title of a commentary to the nighaṇṭavas or Vedic Glossary. [√vac + nis.]
2314: nir-guṇa, a. without a string, 185; void of good qualities, 185; worthless, bad.
2318: nir-bhara, a. 	—1. without measure, much; -am, adv. very; -am prasupta, fast asleep; 	—2. full of.
2319: nir-mala, a. without impurity; pure; clear.
2320: nir-lakṣya, a. not to be perceived, avoiding notice. [see nis 3.]
2321: nir-vaṃśa, a. without family; alone in the world.
2323: nir-viśeṣa, a. without distinction; undistinguished;  alike; like.
2324: nirviśeṣākṛti, a. having like appearance,  looking just alike. [ākṛti.]
2325: nivāra, m. the warding off. [√1vṛ, ‘cover,’ + ni.]
2326: nívīta, ppl. hung, i. e. draped, with hangings,  esp. with the sacred cord; as n. [1176a], the wearing the sacred cord about the neck; the sacred cord itself. [√vyā + ni.]
2327: nivṛtta, ppl. 	—1. turned away; esp. of an action which is turned away, i. e. not directed (to any ulterior purpose or object),  free from hope of reward in this world or the next, disinterested, opp. of pravṛtta, q. v.; 	—2. having turned away from, and so abstaining from, 293. [√vṛt + ni.]
2328: nivéśana, n. a going in and settling down to rest; resting-place; sleeping-place, bed, 1058; dwelling, 86. [√viś + ni: for mg, cf. bhavana.]
2331: niścaya, m. (ascertainment, determination,  i. e.) a fixed opinion or a firm resolve. [poss. fr. √3 ci, ‘notice, look,’ + nis; but better, perhaps, fr. √1ci + nis, and so, ‘an un-piling, i. e. discrimination, determination. ’]
2332: niścala, a. not moving. [nis + cala: see nis 3.]
2333: niścita, ppl. determined, decided; -am, adv. decidedly, surely. [see under niścaya. ]
2334: niḥśreyasa, a. without a superior, i. e. best; as n. final beatitude. [nis + śreyasa: acct, 13053.]
2335: niḥśvāsa, m. breathing out, expiration; sigh. [√śvas + nis.]
2336: niḥśvāsa-parama, a. having sighs as chief thing, much addicted to sighing. [1302b.]
2337: niṣadha, m. pl. the Nishadhans, name of a people; Nishadha, name of a country, 17 N., 43.
2338: niṣadhādhipa, m. ruler or king of the Nishadhans. [adhipa.]
2339: niṣūdana, m. finisher (in its colloquial sense), one who makes an end of, destroyer.  [√sūd + ni.]
2340: niṣeka, m. an injecting, esp. of semen, impregnation; the ceremony performed upon impregnation. [√sic + ni.]
2341: niṣevin, a. devoting one's self to; cohabiting with, 6722. [√sev + ni.]
2342: niṣkramaṇa, n. the stepping out; esp. the first going out with a child. [√kram + nis.]
2345: nís, adv. prep. 	—1. out, forth; 	—2. in cpds [13052 end], having…away, without…,  e. g. nirantara; --3. in cpds, not, e. g. niścala.
2346: √nī (náyati, -te; ninā́ya [800b], ninyé; ánaiṣīt, áneṣṭa [882]; neṣyáti, -te; nītá; nétum; nītvā́; -nī́ya; nīyáte; nāyáyati [1042b]). lead, 2415; guide; conduct, 8520; carry, 3919, etc.; carry off, 3615, 4317; vyāghratāṃ nī, bring to tiger-ness, change into a tiger; vaśaṃ nī, bring into one's power. + anu, (draw along toward one, i. e.) try to win or conciliate by friendly words. + abhi, bring hither to. + ā, bring to, 2914; bring, 319; bring (one liquid) into (another, loc.), mix, 10114; caus. cause to be fetched, 505. + ud, bring up; rescue (as a drowning man from the water), 9010. + upa, take unto one's self, of the teacher who receives a youth of one of the three free castes as pupil, and at the same time invests him with the sacramental cord, thus conferring spiritual rebirth,  and making him a full member of his caste; see upanāyana; upanīta, invested with the sacramental cord. + pari, lead around (a cow, steer), 9114, 10522; esp. lead a bride around the fire (as wedding ceremony), page 99. + pra, 	—1. bring forward; 	—2. as liturgical terminus technicus, convey the sacrificial fire and water to their places on and near the altar; praṇītās (sc. āpas), holy water; 	—3. bring forward (one's feelings), i. e. come out with or manifest one's affection,  915. + vi, lead; guide; train; discipline.
2348: nīcá, a. low, not high; morally and socially low. [inorganic transfer-form (1209a) fr. nīc-ā́, q. v.]
2349: nīcā́, adv. down, low. [adverbially accented instr.--instead of nī́c-ā, 1112e--fr. ny-àñc.]
2350: nīcā́-vayas [418], a. whose strength is low; exhausted. [1306.]
2351: nīḍá, Vedic nīḻá, m. n. 	—1. (place for settling down, i. e.) resting-place; 	—2. esp. bird's nest. [for ni-zd-a, i. e. ni-s(a)d-a --198b3 --√sad + ni: cf. Lat. nīdus, Ger. Nest, Eng. nest: for ḻ, see Whitney 54.]
2353: nīti, f. 	—1. cónduct, esp. right and sagacious conduct; the knowledge of all that governs virtuous and discreet and statesman-like behavior; political and social ethics; 	—2. leading. [√nī, ‘condúct.’]
2354: nīti-jñá, a. knowing how to conduct one's self discreetly.
2355: nīti-vidyā, f. knowledge of nīti or political and social ethics, esp. as it concerns princes.
2356: nīti-śāstra, n. doctrine or science of political and social ethics.
2357: nītha, m. a leading; nīthá, n. (way, and so, like the German Weise) a musical air, song. [√nī, 1163a.]
2359: nīrasa, a. sapless, dried up; tasteless; insipid, 5411. [nis + rasa, 174, 179.]
2360: nīruj, a. without disease; healthy, 223. [nis + rúj, 174, 179.]
2361: nī́la, a. dark-colored, esp. dark blue; as n. indigo; nīlī, f. indigo. [hence, through the Arabic an-nîl, for al-nîl, ‘the indigo-plant, ’ come Eng. anil and aniline.]
2364: nīlasaṃdhāna-bhāṇḍa, n. vat for the mixing, i. e. preparing of indigo.
2366: nīvā́ra, m. wild rice; sing. the plant; pl. the grains.
2368: √nu (návate; nunā́va; ánūṣṭa; nutá; -nútya). cry aloud; shout; exult; praise. + pra, murmur; hum; esp. utteṛ the sacred syllable om.
2369: nú, adv. 	—1a. now, at once, temporal; 	—1b. now, continuative; adhā nu, so now, 798; 	—1c. now, introductory, 701; 	—1d. so then, in encouraging or summoning; 	—1e. now, pray, in questions, 521, 718, 5120, 748, 7812; 	—2. asseverative: nakir nu, surely no one or nothing, 7320; mā́ nú, in order that surely not, 8610; 	—3. w. relatives: yā nu, whatsoever, 742; yān nu, i. e. yāt nu, as long soever as, 7913. [in V. often nū́: cf. νύ, νῦν, Lat. nun-c, Ger. nu, nun, AS. nu, nū, Eng. now: see also náva, nū́tana, nūnám.]
2370: √nud (nudáti, -te; nunóda, nunudé; ánutta [881]; notsyáti, -te; nuttá, nunná; -núdya). push; thrust. + parā, thrust away; move from its place. + pra, push forward; set in motion. + vi, drive asunder or away; turn away, esp. from cares, like the Eng. di-vert; amuse. [for mg, cf. also dis-port and s-port.]
2372: nū́tana, a. of now; recent; young. [nú, 1245e.]
2374: nṛ́ [370, 3715, 9, 10], m. man; hero; used also of gods: of the Maruts, 744, 7718. [cf. ἀνήρ, stem ἀνερ, ‘man’; Old Lat. nero, stem nerōn, ‘manly, strong’; Lat. Nero.]
2376: √nṛt (nṛ́tyati, -te; nanárta; ánartīt; nartiṣyáti; nṛttá; nártitum; nartitvā́ ). dance.
2378: nṛ-pa, m. protector of men, i. e. prince, king.
2379: nṛ-páti, m. lord of men, i. e. prince, king. [acct, 1267a.]
2380: nṛmṇá, n. virtus, manliness, courage, strength. [fr. nṛ (1224c), as virtus fr. vir.]
2383: netra, n. eye. [‘leader,’ √nī, 1185a: for mg, cf. nayana.]
2384: néd, adv. lest, in order that not, w. accented verb (595d) in the subjunctive (581e), 8417. [ná + íd, 1111a2.]
2387: nairukta, a. pertaining to the Nirukta; as m. an etymologist. [nírukta, 1208f.]
2388: naiṣadha, a. pertaining to Nishadha; as m. prince of the Nishadhans, i. e. Nala. [niṣadha, 1208f.]
2389: nó, adv. and not, 2114; no ced, and if not, see ced. [ná + u.]
2391: naú [361a], f. boat; ship. [cf. ναῦς, Lat. nāvis, ‘ship’; perhaps AS. naca, ‘skiff’: perhaps ‘the swimmer,’ √snū, cf. √snā.]
2392: nyag-ródha, m. Ficus índica, banyan tree. [‘downwards-growing’: nyañc (1249a) + rodha.]
2394: nyāyá, m. 	—1. (that to which a thing goes back, i. e.) rule, norm; 	—2. (that in which a thing goes, i. e.) way; 	—3. esp. the right way, propriety. [√i + ni, 1148. 2.]
2395: nyāyya, a. regular, normal, right; -am, adv. rightly; properly. [nyāyá, 1211.]
2396: nyāsa, m. a putting down, commitment. [√2as + ni, ‘throw down.’]
2399: pakṣá, m. 	—1. wing, 932; 	—2. side, of a door or of the hair of the head; 	—3. half, esp. of a lunar month, 271, 5719, cf. kṛṣṇa-, śukla-; --4. side, i. e. party, 3718.
2401: pakṣín, a. winged, 9219; as m. bird, 223. [pakṣa.]
2402: pakṣimṛgatā, f. condition of bird or of beast. [fr. pakṣin + mṛga: 1237, 1252.]
2403: pakṣi-śāvaka, m. young of a bird; birdling. [pakṣin.]
2405: paṅktí, f. set or series or row of five; row in general. [páñca, 1157. 4.]
2406: paṅkti-krama, m. order of a row; -eṇa, in a row, 3914.
2407: √pac (pácati, -te; papā́ca, pecé [794e]; ápākṣīt; pakṣyáti, -te; páktum; paktvā́ ). cook, by baking or boiling or roasting; ripen. [cf. πέσσω, ‘cook’; πέπ-ων, ‘ripe’; Lat. coquo, ‘cook’; borrowed AS. noun cōc, Eng. cook.] + vi, cook thoroughly; pass. be brought to maturity; ripen (of an action), i. e. come to its consequences or issue.
2408: páñca [4833], num. five. [cf. πέντε, Aeolic πέμπε, Lat. quinque, Goth. fimf, AS. fīf, Eng. five.]
2409: pañca-tantra, n. Panchatantra, name of a collection of fables. [‘having five divisions or books.’]
2410: pañca-tapas, a. having five fires, of an ascetic who sits between four fires, one at each cardinal point, and with the burning sun above.
2411: pañcatva, n. fiveness; esp. dissolution of the body into the five elements (earth, water, fire, air, ether, see bhūta and 665N.), i. e. death; w. gam, die. [pañca, 1239.]
2412: páñca-pada, f. -ī, a. having (taken) five steps. [acct, 1300.]
2416: √paṭ (pāṭáyati, etc.). split, slit. + ud, open out.
2417: paṭa, m. woven stuff; cloth; garment.
2419: paṭu, a. 	—1. sharp; and so 	—2. fig. (nearly like Eng. sharp), clever.
2420: √paṭh (páṭhati; papā́ṭha; paṭhitá; paṭhitvā́; pāṭháyati). read aloud, 5423, 559; recite, 1711; repeat to one's self, study, 2211; caus. teach to talk, 1915.
2421: √paṇ (páṇati, -te; paṇitá). 	—1. bargain; buy; 	—2. bet, wage, stake, play. [prob. for *paln: cf. πέρνημι and πωλέω, ‘sell’; Ger. feil, ‘for sale, venal.’] + ā, in āpaṇa, ‘market.’ + vi, sell.
2422: paṇa, m. 	—1. bargain, stipulation, 4514; 	—2. wage, gage, prize; 	—3. a certain coin, 4716. [√paṇ.]
2423: paṇí, m. 	—1. bargainer, who gives nought without return; chafferer, haggler, and so 	—2. niggard; esp. one who is stingy towards the gods, an impious person; 	—3. a malicious demon. [√paṇ.]
2424: paṇḍitá, a. learned; as m. learned man, Anglo-Indian pandit.
2426: páṇya, grdv. to be bargained for or bartered;  as n. article of trade. [√paṇ, 963.]
2427: √pat (pátati, -te; papā́ta, petús [794e]; ápaptat; patiṣyáti; patitá; pátitum; patitvā́; -pátya; pātáyati, -te). 	—1. fly; move swiftly through the air; 	—2. descend,  let one's self down; cast one's self at, 268; 	—3. fall down, tumble down, 348, 402, 5; fall (morally), fall from one's caste; fall down (dead); 	—4. fall upon, be directed to, 136; 	—5. fall or get into, 228, 9; --caus. cause to fly; hurl (a curse), 4911. [cf. πέτομαι, ‘fly’; πί-πτω, ‘fall’; Lat. peto, ‘fall upon, make for, seek’: see also pattra.] + anu, fly after, pursue. + ud, fly up. + sam-ud, fly or spring up together, 36, 814. + ni, fly down; light, 38; tumble into, 3613; caus. cause to fall; kill, 3211, 3317. + saṃ-ni, fall together, 9920; come together; caus. bring together or convene, 919. + parā, fly off, 931.
2429: patatrín, a. winged; as m. bird. [patatra. ]
2431: páti [343b], m. 	—1. master, possessor; lord; ruler, 42; 	—2. then (like Eng. lord), husband, 97, 895, 8619, 6413. [cf. πόσις, ‘husband’; Lat. impos, stem im-pot, ‘not master of’; Goth. faϸs in bruϸ-faϸ-s, ‘bridegroom. ’]
2432: pati-ghnī, a. f. husband-slaying. [formally a fem. to pati-han, 402.]
2433: patitvá, n. condition of spouse; wedlock. [pati.]
2434: pati-loká, m. husband's place, abode of the husband in the future life.
2436: patisthānīya, a. belonging to or in the husband's place; as m. husband's representative. [patisthāna, 1215.]
2437: páttra, n. 	—1. feather; wing; 	—2. (plumage of a tree, i. e.) leaf--for mg, cf. parṇa; --3. a leaf for writing on; a written leaf, 5419. [√pat: cf. πτερόν, ‘wing’; Lat. penna and Old Lat. pesna (for *petna), ‘wing’; Ger. Fed-er, Eng. feath-er.]
2438: pattra-śāka, n. leaf-vegetable, a vegetable consisting chiefly of leaves.
2439: pátnī, f. 	—1. mistress, lady; 	—2. then (like Eng. lady), wife. [fem. to páti, just as πότνια, ‘lady,’ is to πόσις.]
2440: patsutaḥ-śī́ [352], a. lying at the feet.
2441: patsutás, adv. at the feet. [fr. patsú, loc. pl. of pád, 1098b.]
2445: pathi-rákṣi, a. guarding the paths. [panthan, 1249a: acct, 1276.]
2446: pathya, a. (pertaining to the way, course, or progress of a thing, and so) suitable, wholesome; pathyā́, f. pathway. [path, 1212d 1.]
2447: √pad (pádyate; papā́da, pedé [794e]; ápatta [882]; patsyáte, -ti; panná [957d]; páttum; -pádya; pādáyati). 	—1. go, step, tread, only w. prepositions and in derivatives; 	—2. fall, sink down (from fatigue), perish. [connection between 1 and 2 not clear: uncompounded verb very rare: see under pád and padá.] + ā, come unto; get into (a condition); esp. get in trouble. + vy-ā, fall away, perish; caus. destroy; kill. + ud, go forth or out of; come into existence; be produced; utpannam annam, food (not cooked for the occasion, but) already on hand, 1041; utpanne kārye, when the emergency has arisen, 3814; --caus. engender, 238; produce; get, 4217. + praty-ud, in ppl. pratyutpanna, ready or on hand to meet an emergency. + upa, fall upon; happen, take place, 10010; come to, get at, reach; upapanna, (having gotten at [9522], i. e.) in possession of, endowed with, 14, 23. + prati, 	—1. step to; enter upon, 6618; 	—2. get into (a condition), 4915; get at, acquire, attain, 9810; get back again, 6017; 	—3. go to meet, and so (like the Lat. ac-cēdere), accede, yield; say yes to; consent,  4812. + vi, fall asunder, 939; come to nought, get into trouble. + sam, 	—1. turn out well, succeed, prosper; 	—2. become, 4512, 4718; 	—3. fall together, be united with; sampanna, endowed with, 210.
2448: pád [391], m. foot. [√pad: cf. πόδ-α, Lat. pĕd-em, Eng. foot.]
2449: padá, n. 	—1. step, 1721, 9923; 	—2. footstep; 	—3. foot, 866; 	—4. standing-place, stead, place; home, 564; station, position, 411. [√pad: cf. πέδον, ‘ground’; Lat. op-pedum, op-pidum, ‘town, (on or over the field)’; peda, ‘footprint’; AS. fœt, ‘step, going, journey,’ whence fetian, ‘go for,’ Eng. fetch.]
2450: padma, m. n. lotus, Nelumbium speciosum (not the plant, but the flower, which closes at evening).
2451: padma-garbha, a. containing lotuses; Lotus-filled, name of a lake. [see garbha 2.]
2452: padma-rāga, a. having the color of a lotus; as m. ruby. [1296.]
2453: pánthan [433], m. road, path, way. [cf. πἀτος, ‘path’; Lat. pont-em, ‘path, bridge’: Eng. path and Ger. Pfad, if they belong here at all, must be regarded as very early borrowings, fr. the Greek πάτος, or poss. from the Scythian.]
2456: payo-mukha, a. having milk on the face or surface. [payas, 1303.]
2457: pára [5254], a. 	—1. far, distant, more distant,  further off, 864; 	—2. following, later, future; 	—3. being beyond, surpassing,  summus; chief, 687; best, 3610; utmost,  113; greatest, 4417; highest, 10311; at end of cpds [1302b], having…as chief thing, given over to…, devoted to…; 	—4. a. and subst. other, 6413; eka…para, the one…the other, 5319; another, 3022; strange, hostile; stranger, 246; foe, 2910, 3719. [√2pṛ, ‘bring across’; cf. πέρᾱ, ‘beyond’; Lat. peren-die, ‘the day after,’ i. e. ‘day after to-morrow’; Eng. far and fore.]
2460: para-pakṣa, m. party of the foe.
2461: para-patnī, f. wife of a stranger.
2462: param, adv. beyond; w. abl. [1128], after, 6020. [pára, 1111c.]
2463: paramá [5253], a. 	—1. farthest, extreme, last; of heaven, highest, 8313; so 853; 	—2. chiefest, 291; supreme; most excellent,  1517; at end of cpds [1302b], having …as supreme object, devoted to…; 	—3. advly in cpds, before an adj. [1279], highly, exceedingly. [pára, 474.]
2467: parame-ṣṭhín, a. standing in the highest place; supreme, as epithet of Prajāpati.  [parame (1250c) + sthin, 186.]
2468: para-loka, m. the other or future world.
2469: parás, adv. far; in the distance; beyond; w. advly used instr. [1127] enā́, beyond here, i. e. beyond, RV. x. 125. 8. [see pára.]
2470: parástāt, adv. beyond; afterwards, at the end. [parás, 1100b.]
2471: paras-para, one another; parasparam and parasparatas, adv. with one another; mutually. [an agglomeration (1314c) of paras (nom. s. m. of para) and para: the syntactical forms sometimes correspond to the logical relation of the two parts--so, e. g., in parasparaṃ nindanti, ‘they scold, the one the other’--but have come to be stereotyped and used often where the logical relation would require other case forms: cf. anyonya.]
2473: párā, adv. to a distance, away, forth. [cf. παρά, w. gen., ‘away from, from beside’; Lat. per- in per-īre and Ger. ver- in ver-gehen, ‘pass away, perish’; Eng. for- in for-bear, ‘hold off from.’]
2474: parākrama, m. s. and pl. bold advance; courage; strength. [√kram + parā.]
2475: parāṅ-mukha, a. having the face averted; turning the back upon, avoiding. [parāñc, 1249a, 217, 161.]
2476: párāñc [409a], f. párācī, a. directed away; averted; turning the back. [parā + añc, 407.]
2477: parārtha, m. the sake of others; -am, -e, adv. for others. [artha, 1302c 4.]
2479: pári, adv. around; prep. w. abl.: from around, 878; from, 7515. [cf. περί, ‘around.’]
2480: parigha, m. iron bar for locking a gate. [√han + pari, 1143c, 333: for mg, cf. Ger. Schlag, ‘coach-door,’ and schlagen, ‘strike’: force of prep. unclear.]
2482: pari-jana, m. the surrounding folk, περίπολοι; retinue. [1289a.]
2484: pariṇeya, grdv. to be led around. [√nī + pari.]
2487: paridhí, m. (a put-around, i. e.) enclosure, fence, protection, 8610; in the language of the sacrifice, the three green sticks laid about the altar fire and supposed to hold it together, 10513, 3. [√1dhā, ‘put,’ + pari, 1155. 2e.]
2488: paripanthín, a. besetting the path; as m. waylayer. [pari + panthan, 1310a and c end.]
2489: paribhū́ [352], a. being around, encompassing.  [√bhū + pari, 323.]
2491: parivartin, a. turning round, circling, constantly returning into itself. [√vṛt + pari.]
2492: parivāra, m. that which surrounds, i. e. retinue. [√1vṛ, ‘cover,’ + pari.]
2493: pariśrít, f. (encloser, i. e.) one of the little stones by which the sacrificial altar is surrounded. [√śri + pari, ‘enclose’: 383b.]
2494: parisaṃkhyā, f. complete tale or enumeration;  sum. [√khyā + pari-sam.]
2496: párus, n. knot; joint, of a plant or of the body. [perhaps ‘a fullness,’ √1pṛ, ‘fill’: cf. párvan.]
2497: parókṣa, a. beyond the eye, out of sight, invisible; -e, adv. [1116], behind one's back. [for paro.'kṣa, i. e. parás + akṣá, ‘eye’: 1310a.]
2498: parokṣārtha, m. invisible thing, the invisible. [artha.]
2499: parkaṭī, f. waved-leaved fig-tree, Ficus infectoria.
2500: parṇá, n. 	—1. wing; plume, feather; 	—2. leaf--for mg, cf. pattra. [√*spṛ (1177a), see under √sphur: cf. Lithuanian spárna, ‘wing’; Ger. Farn, Eng. fern, so called (like πτερίς, ‘fern,’--cf. πτερόν, ‘feather,’) from its feathery fronds.]
2501: paryālocana, n. deliberation; -ā, f. plan, consilium. [√loc + pary-ā, 1150. 2a2.]
2502: párvata, 	—1. a. consisting of knots or ragged masses, used of a mountain, giri; as m. 	—2. mountain, 276, 9219; hill; 	—3. cloud-mountain, 702; 	—4. rock or bowlder, 8611; 	—5. Parvata, name of a Rishi, companion of Nārada (q. v.), 59. [fr. párvan, cf. 1245c: cf. Παῤῥασία (*παρϝατια), sc. πόλις, i. e. ‘Hil-ton.’]
2505: parvatopatyakā, f. mountain-lowland, lowland by a mountain range. [upatyakā. ]
2506: párvan, n. knot, joint. [‘fullness,’ √1pṛ, ‘fill,’ 1169. 1a: cf. párus.]
2508: √palāy (pálāyate; palāyā́ṃ cakre; ápalāyiṣṭa; palāyiṣyáti, -te; pálāyita; palāyitum; palāyya). flee; depart, cease, 4019. [quasi-root fr. √i, ‘go,’ + parā, ‘away,’ see 1087c and c2: quite different is √pālaya, ‘protect.’]
2510: pávana, n. instrument for purifying; winnowing-fan. [√pū, 1150.]
2511: √1paś, orig. spaś (páśyati, -te; in Veda: paspaśé; áspaṣṭa [834c]; spaṣṭá; later: dadárśa, etc.). 	—1. see; 	—2. perceive; behold; 	—3. look; 	—4. look on, 397; gaze, 137; 	—5. (see i. e.) experience, 2016, 351; 	—6. look upon, 2123, 4015; consider as; 	—7. see with the spiritual eye (as seers and poets), 949. [for the initial s, see the perfect and vi-spaṣṭa: cf. σκέπ-τ-ομαι, ‘look about’; Lat. specio, ‘behold’; Ger. spähen, ‘spy,’ Old High Ger. spehōn, whence, through Old French espier, the Eng. espy, and shortened spy.] + anu, look along or spy out (e. g. a path for some one, i. e.), disclose or show, 837. + vi, see in places apart, distinguish, see clearly; víspaṣṭa, clear.
2512: √2paś, fasten, bind, in derivs, see paśú, pā́śa. [cf. πάσσαλος, *πακ-ϳαλος, ‘peg’; Lat. pac-iscor, ‘bind myself, agree’; pax, ‘agreement, peace’; pang-ere, ‘make fast,’ pac-tum, ‘agreed upon’; Goth. fah-an, AS. fōn, *fōh-an, ‘fasten on, take hold of’; Eng. verb fang, ‘seize,’ noun fang, ‘seizingtooth’;  connection of fing-er (‘grasper, holder’ ?), doubtful: cf. also Goth. fagrs, ‘fitting,’ AS. fœgr, Eng. fair; AS. ge-fēgan, Eng. fay, Ger. fügen, ‘fit together,’ trans., and Eng. fadge, ‘fit together or agree,’ intrans.]
2513: paśú, m. cattle, 902--a single head or a herd; domestic animal (opp. to mṛga, ‘wild beast’), 672; esp. beast for sacrifice, 1016. [prop. ‘tethered (beasts),’ √2paś, ‘fasten’: cf. Lat. pec-u, Ger. Vieh, ‘cattle,’ AS. feoh, ‘cattle, property,’ Eng. fee, orig. ‘property,’ then ‘payment.’]
2514: paśu-ghna, a. slaying cattle; as m. cattle-slayer.
2516: paśu-bandhá, m. animal sacrifice. [‘binding of beast’ to sacrificial post.]
2517: paśumánt, a. rich in cattle. [paśu, 1235 and b.]
2518: paśu-roman, n. a hair of an animal.
2520: paścá, a. hinder; later; west; paścā́t, as adv. [1114c]: 	—1. behind; after, 3923; 	—2. later, afterwards, 2917, 384; thereupon,  3613, 3917, 4012; paścā́t, as prep. w. gen. [1130]: 	—3. after, 512; 	—4. to the west of, 9817, 10017, 10510. [paścá is an inorganic transfer-stem (1209a) fr. paścā́, q. v.]
2521: paścā́, adv. behind; later; west. [adverbially accented instr.--instead of páśc-ā, i. e. pás-(a)c-ā, 1112c--fr. *pás-añc (407): with pas cf. Lat. pos-terus, ‘later,’ etc.]
2523: paścima, a. last, 5216; westerly. [paśca: cf. 1224a and b.]
2524: √1pā (píbati, -te [671, 749]; papaú, papé; ápāt; pāsyáti, -te; pītá [954c]; pā́tum; pītvā́; -pā́ya, -pī́ya). drink. [cf. πέ-πω-κα, ‘have drunk’; Πῖ-σα, ‘The Burn, The Fountain’; Lat. pō-tus, ‘drunk’; bibo, *pi-b-o, ‘drink.’]
2525: √2pā (pā́ti; ápāsīt; pā́tum). protect; keep; for so-called caus., see pālaya. [cf. πέ-πᾱ-μαι, ‘have kept, possess’; πῶ-ν, ‘herd’; Lat. pa-sc-o, ‘keep, pasture’; see go-pā́.] + pari, protect around.
2529: pā́ka, a. 	—1. of a calf, young; 	—2. simple.  [lit. ‘sucking,’ √1pā, ‘drink.’]
2530: pāka-dūrvā́, f. young millet-grass. [pā́ka + dū́rvā: acct, 12802.]
2531: pāṭala, a. pale red; as m. Bignonia suaveolens.
2532: pāṭali, f. Bignonia suaveolens or trumpetflower.  [cf. pāṭala.]
